dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF PHOTOGRAPHS 1
dialogues.text: They succeed one another with the SOUND of a CAMERA CLICK sharply. This is a composite of NORMA RAE WEBSTER's life, glimpses of her early days, a burgeoning and a metamorphosis: She is seen as an infant, sitting in her bath ina galvanized tub, hair twisted into a kewpie-doll peak, beribboned. Norma at seven, front tooth out, a large grin splitting h face. At twelve in a bathing suit, a pigeon-toed stance, arms folded self-consciously across her chest. At fifteen, facing front, arrogant now, breasts jutting o hip cocked. At eighteen, her arm around a sailor's shoulder, wearing his hat at a rakish angle. At twenty on a front porch with a cluster of girls, Norma at the center, mouth black with too much lipstick, holdin a ukulele. At twenty-two, holding a bridal bouquet, wearing a floppy hat, perplexed, faintly forlorn, on the edge of the unkno At twenty-four, defiant, thumbing her nose at a sign read "Simpson's Secretarial School." At twenty-six, sitting with her back against a tree, twe young children tumbled in her lap, looking fond and frazz At twenty-eight, in a monkey-pert waitress!’ outfit, balancing a tray, ground lost. At thirty, a photographer's formal portrait, unguarded, beautiful, unfathomable. At thirty-two, mature, strong, with humor, without illusi

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 2 ,
dialogues.text: She moves -- and the photograph becomes film. cont. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pr 2 2 Cont. CAMERA PULLS BACK. In the noise, amid the flying lint, OQ she is in an aisle tight with machines, monitoring loo

dialogues.speaker: THE MILL 3
dialogues.text: The place bursts on the SCREEN like a battlefield, full o a jolting, nerve-shattering din. In the enormous space, rows and rows of old WOODEN LOOMS ROAR like waterfalls an shake the floors with ceaseless trembling vibrations. The sound is deafening, the constant punishing, racketing mot disorienting. There are no windows, no sunlight, only blank, brick walls; it is a seasonless, timeless world in which men and women cannot hear themselves think, do not think. They are bound and shackled to the work.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: Steam vents spew mist into every corner to keep the yarn hot and wet. Mosquito netting rises from the floor and disappears overhead in the high dark reaches toward the ceiling. There is a permanent haze everywhere made by lin coming off the rolls of terry cloth, rolls as high as a m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The work begins in "the raw" where the cotton bales are brought in and men with surgical masks covering their nos and mouths rip apart the bales of cotton, feeding them in 1 the mouths of hoppers that shred the cotton fibers and So them apart. Cotton dust and lint fill the air like snow, coating everyone from head to toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carders are next on the line, then spinners and doffers. Almost all the work can be seen in this vast room, the si of an enormous pasture, without interior walls. The rolls of terry cloth slowly unwind behind the backs of the side henmers » passing yard by yard through the women's sewing machines.

dialogues.speaker: LEONA WITCHARD 6
dialogues.text: grey-streaked, traces of beauty still visible. She works with her face close to a spider web of threads, her hands rapidly guiding them. It is work of intense concentration demanding, exhausting.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON WITCHARD . 7
dialogues.text: Norma's father, a large, handsome man, fractious, expansi stands at a row of bobbins, doing back-breaking stoop lab © Cont. bes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 Cont. A shrill WHISTLE SOUNDS. It is the break for lunch. Vernon Witchard straightens, clutching his back, punished by the morning's work.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LUNCHROOM 8
dialogues.text: A narrow space with a long window looking out on the work floor. Signs are posted: "Give your chair to a spinner; they only have 15 minutes." The mill hands make quick wor of their meal. There is little conversation; they are already too tired to talk. Norma munches on an apple. BONNIE MAE, a cheerful sparrow of a woman from the folding tables, speaks to her.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE MAE
dialogues.text: You just eating an apple for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm dieting.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE MAE
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta keep my strength up. (eats heartily, biting into a thick sandwich) I put this jelly up myself. on Sunday, Roscoe and I put up over sixty quarts of peaches. What'd you do over the weekend, Norma?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Soaked my feet.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE MAE
dialogues.text: Saw you downtown. Your friend drives a big car.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: If you'd looked on the motel register, you'd a seen my name there, too.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE MAE
dialogues.text: It's none of my business... Norma turns to look at her mother beside her. The woman's eyes are closed, her head rests back against the tile. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Momma, you haven't opened your sack. Leona remains motionless.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Momma, don't you want your lunch? Still the woman doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Momma ! Still Leona remains with her eyes closed. Alarmed, Norma shakes her and Leona finally opens her eyes, looking at h daughter blankly.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What is it, Momma? Don't you feel good?

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Don't you hear me? Momma! (bends close to her, bawling) Momma, Momma, Momma! Leona doesn't respond. Norma is on her feet instantly. Sh hauls her mother up, grabs her by the arm, and, pulling after her, she runs.

dialogues.speaker: THE WEAVING ROOM 9
dialogues.text: It is a headlong race across the length of the mill, Norm ahead and frantic, her mother in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. WATSON is confronted by an agitated, flaring Norma, while Leona sits with her hands calmly folded in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: She didn't hear me} She didn't hear one word I said! She doesn't hear you now!

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATSON
dialogues.text: You know this happens, Norma Rae. It happens all the time. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, not to my momma!

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATSON
dialogues.text: It'll pass off. It's just temporary.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That makes it all right, huh? She's only deaf for an hour, she's only deaf for two hours, she's only deaf all day!

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATSON
dialogues.text: (mildly) She can get herseif another job.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What other job in this town? "his is the only job.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WATSON
dialogues.text: I'll give her a note. They'll send her home.

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Come on, Momma. You're nothing to any of 'em. She takes her mother's arm and shepherds her out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE YARD OF THE WITCHARD HOUSE 11
dialogues.text: The back of the shotgun house sits in an almost grassless plot. In one corner of the yard a shade tree struggles to live. It is still daylight, and underneath, on a straight backed kitchen chair, Leona Witchard sits quietly. She sits very still, her face tilted toward the meager green above her; she is in a reverie, on the wings of a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma is at the sink, washing the dishes, her father Vern towel in hand, dries. Norma, as she works, watches her mother through the open window. She finally calls out to her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You all right out there? Without turning, Leona responds in her quiet, patient voi Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: OQ Yes. I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You'll get all bitten up.

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: I'm coming in soon. Norma returns to the job at hand. She suddenly wipes her hands briskly on a towel.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna let this pot soak.

dialogues.speaker: RNON
dialogues.text: (mildly) There's one soaking from breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, now it's got company. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LIVING ROOM / 13
dialogues.text: SG In the sparsely furnished room, two children, CRAIG an MILLIE, sit raptly watching TELEVISION. Norma enters.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Ten more minutes of that junk and then you.do your homework.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I did it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: '¢' in writing, 'C’ in spelling, 'D! in reading -~ you haven't peen doing too much homework.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Sssshhh. I wanna hear.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'll ssshhh you. She goes into her bedroom, strips off her blouse, sniffs ! the armpits, grimaces and tosses it aside. She takes on from the closet and puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Vernon looms in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: What're you getting fixed up for?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm going into town.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: What do you need in town?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Things.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Well...I'll drive you in.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You got 'Bonanzat on next.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I'll miss it. Same every week anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm going to J.C. Penney's to buy myself some panties and a white cotton brassiere, size 32C. You wanna come sit on a little stool outside the dressing room and have all the ladies look at you, come on.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think I care to do that... (then) »eeYou comin! straight back?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No. Next I'm going to the drugstore to buy myself some Kotex pads and a.Cosmopolitan Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Well...then you coming home?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah. By. then I'll be so tired out from all the excitement, I'll be coming home. The front DOORBELL RINGS. Vernon goes to answer it. 558

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR 15
dialogues.text: REUBEN WARSHOVSKY stands on the stoop. He has two large suitcases and is dressed in tennis shoes blue jeans and a T-shirt. Reuben is lean, sharp, full of nervous and intellectual energy; his view of life wavers between the jaundiced and the merry. He is a master of finagle and accommodation; he is purposeful and principle He is fully mobilized always, however calm and easy his manner may be.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Witchard?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: That's right. Vernon Witchard, Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: My name is Reuben Warshovsky.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Warshovsky? What kind of name is that? ,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It's the kind you have to spell for telephone operators and headwaiters.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'd like to get me a room with a mill family.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: What for? We got a hotel with 12 rooms and a motel with 24 rooms.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I want to get to know some mill hands. Close up.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Why is that? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 15 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Witchard...I got into town about an hour ago, parked my rented car, got out, and, before I could adjust my crotch, the Chief of Police was on me, saying ‘Who are you, I don't know you! and 'what the hell are you doing here?! I told him I was a labor organizer, come to put a union in the 0.P. Henley textile mill, and he said, 'The fuck you are!! gave me a ticket and told me to get my ass elsewhere right quick. Norma has appeared behind her father and listens curiousl

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: He's dead right. As far as I'm concerned, you're all Communists or agitators or crooks or Jews or all four together. Any town you show up, folks get thrown out of work and get their heads busted.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: What .do you make an hour, Mr. Witchard?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Two dollars and eighteen cents!

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: When did you have your last cost-of-living raise?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I never had that.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Mr. Witchard, with today's inflation, that makes you a shlemiel,.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: You calling me some kind of name or other?!

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You're underpaid. You're overworked. They're shafting you, right up to your tonsils. You need me. Cont.  558 10 15 cont.1

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: If you hurry, you can get to the fence before my dog bites you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What're you telling him that for? We don't have a dog.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (looking at her father) You don't need one. He hefts the heavy suitcases, turns and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place has never seen better days. It was always none too clean, familiar with the hot-pillow trade and other transients. The rooms have a view of a blacktop parking area and a scummy swimming pool. Norma sits in the small lobby, flipping through the pages of a magazine, ignored by ALSTON PURVIS, the desk clerk. She looks up with some surprise as Reuben enters, by now footsore and weary. He recognizes her.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: This is one friendly little town you got here. I've been told to shove off, to piss off, and to git off.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (mildly) This place is okay. Just make sure they spray the room for roaches.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'm familiar with roaches. goes to the esk) I'd like a room with a view.

dialogues.speaker: ALSTON
dialogues.text: You got the back alley or the parking lot. Which? Cont.  ©

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 16 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (intervening) Give him 207, Alston. You can't hear the drunks in there. . GEORGE BENSON enters. He is a large man, floridly handsom commanding, with an edge of violence just concealed. He walks straight past Norma for the stairs, making only a peremptory beckoning gesture. She tosses aside the magazi and rises to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHOWER is HEARD RUNNING from the open bathroom. Norma sits on the edge of the torn-apart bed, fastening her bra; she gets up and pulls on her jeans. Her face is impassive; whatever has transpired in the past hour has left her unmoved. George comes in, a towel wrapped around his middie, his hair still streaming. He combs his hair at the mirror, drops of water spraying.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll be back this way next Wednesday. After dinner. I'm having dinner with my wife's folks.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Tonight was the last time, George. He doesn't turn. The. comb simply moves a little more slowly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You don't say, Norma Rae. Isn't that a surprising turn.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No. It's been coming for some time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, isn't that funny, I didn't notice it. Didn't you get your steak dinner? Didn't you get your box of pralines? Didn't you get your French red wine? Didn't you come three times in a row in that bed over there? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 17 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I wasn't counting.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: now turns to ace her) Looks like I don't know what it takes to satisfy you these days.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It just doesn't sit well with me anymore, George. You got your wife, you got your two kids in high school, there's a lot of gossip, I got my two kids... ~ (shrugs) «ee don't know...it just doesn't make me feel good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (flatly) You're here to make me feel good. ~ He advances on her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm not trotting down here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why, you hick. You got dirt under your fingernails, you leave hair in the sink, you pick your teeth with a matchbook -- I've seen you! Why, shit, what are you good for -- to come out of the factory, wash under your armpits, spread your legs for a poke and go home. And you're dumping me! He hits her hard across the mouth; the impact sends her hurtling across the room, slamming against the opposite wall. cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eae a NNEC EERE eae ee = 22a 13 17 Cont.1 She ends up crumpled on the floor, wiping her bloody nos2 with the back of her hand, pausing to look at it. Then sh gets up. She reaches for her bag.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (at the door) You know something? You're absolutely right about me. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: WALKWAY 18
dialogues.text: She stumbles once or twice in the walkway, pauses to shov her blouse inside her pants. Reuben is standing at the open door to his room as she passes it. He speaks coolly.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I heard a hell of a thump.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That was me, getting thrown across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better come in. She follows him into his room.

dialogues.speaker: INT, REUBEN'S ROOM 19
dialogues.text: He goes into the bathroom, returns with a washcloth, dumo ice cubes out of his Coke, hands her the icepack. She put it gingerly against her face.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Sit down. You look a little shaken up. She sits. He notes the condition she's in.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I thought everyone down South was Ashley Wilkes. Cont. 558

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You lie down with dogs, you get fleas (removes rag and shows him her nose) Does this look like it's broken to you?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. Want an aspirin?’

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Band-Aic¢

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Valium.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're a whole drugstore.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Mild hypochondriac. Keep the ice on it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Me and men. I ought to learn to say no from the start. But if it wasn't men, I. don't Know what it would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and begins to wander around. He has already established himself; books are stacked and piled everywhe papers litter the desk, clothes are dumped on the bed and hang from the backs of chairs.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You got a lot of books.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm afraid I'll wake up in a motel room someday with nothing to read but the phone book. Cont.  558 15 20 Cont. She stops at the picture of a girl that has been propped up on the bureau. She studies it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: She's got big eyes.

dialogues.speaker: . REUBEN
dialogues.text: She's also got a big brain.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Dorothy Finkelstein. She's a hotshot labor lawyer out of Harvard.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: She must be your girl friend if you haul her picture around with you.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Well, we sleep together on Sunday mornings and then we read the New York Times. I guess that makes her my girl friend, NORMA’ (holds out her hand) I'm Norma Rae Wilson.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (shaking) Reuben Warshovsky.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (pauses I'm sorry about my daddy. He's got a short fuse.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: My credentials keep me out of a lot of places. But every once in a while, somebody'll open a door and put me in the best bedroom and treat me like I was a@ cousin. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 20 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be my daddy. (then, abruptly) You a Jew?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Born and bred.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I never met a Jew before. I heard they had horns. He pushes his hair back to show her.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Circumcised, yes. Horns, no.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Far as I can see, you don't look any different from us.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah? What makes you different?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: History.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hmmmmm... She looks at him thoughtfully a moment. He is a strange bird. -

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for the ice. She hands back the washcloth.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Any time.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Christ, I hope not. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 IN FRONT OF THE MOTEL | a1 Vernon sits parked at the wheel of his battered blue Dodge. As Norma comes out into the night, he waves his hand and calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Over here, honey, She stops short on the pavement, turns and stares a momen exasperation visible. Then she comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Thought I'd come down and give you a ride home. She merely looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: (slyly) You ain't got any packages.

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: (flatly) I ain't got any explanations, either.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Come on, sweetheart. Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slides in beside him, but she is angry and shows him stony profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a strawberry ice cream cone? It is useless to hold out against him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Sure. You treat me like I'm twelve anyhow. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: That's my girl. Beaming, he pulls away and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MILL 23
dialogues.text: Norma and her parents and a throng of mill workers surge through the chain link fence toward the looming, dirt- streaked, windowless red brick building which will swallo them all for the day. It is a spiritless mass of people, silently set for their labor, carrying with them the weariness of season after season. There are no swapped greetings; this work exacts a toll in mind and muscle. NORMA AND REUBEN a4 As she goes through the fence, she comes face to face wit Reuben again; his energy is up. He thrusts a leaflet from a large stack under his arm at each man and woman who pas Suddenly, he finds he is handing one to Norma. She scans it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: There's too many big words in here. If I don't understand it, they ain't gonna understand it. She shoves it back at him and is immediately lost in the crowd. He stops his activity and stands there in some puzzlement, reading his own flyer once again.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 25
dialogues.text: A bossman, JIMMY JEROME DAVIS, stands in front of her as she is about to enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Morning, Jimmy Jerome. The man gestures back toward the fence with his head.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That fellow a friend of yours, Norma?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Looks like he's getting to be.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Better hotfoot it or you'll be late.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I don't care if I don't get there 'til tomorrow. But she goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pees

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: oN -; 558 sect we pees aaceeeree: 19

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FENCE 26
dialogues.text: The last of the mill hands has entered. Reuben is finaly alone and prepares to go. But as he turns, he finds Jimmy Jerome in his path.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well...one of you guys shows up about every four years -- about the same time we get the locusts.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (flat) What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY '
dialogues.text: My name? My name's Timmy Jerome Davis.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Well, Jimmy Jerome, we already got six of you bossmen in civil contempt. Maybe we can make it seven. '

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (genial) Why, hell, we plaster the toilet with them things. He turns and goes. The gate in the fence closes and Reuben is on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 27
dialogues.text: In the weaving room, the back of her shirt already wet. TEDDY BOB KEELER, a fellow worker, taps her on the should she looks around; he indicates a BOSSMAN beckoning to her from his office.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I already told him I wouldn't go out to dinner with him. What's he want now?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY BOB
dialogues.text: Maybe he wants to make it breakfast, Norma Rae. She makes a deprecating gesture and marches off to the summons.

dialogues.speaker: INT, OFFICE 28
dialogues.text: It is quiet in here behind the large plateglass window through which the entire activity in the weaving room can cont.  0 » 20 28 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: be surveyed. TOMMY GARDNER waits for Norma behind a d He has the hard look of a hard-living man, used to dealin with hunting dogs and menials. Norma enters and goes on the attack.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, I didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: Norma, you got the biggest mouth in this mill. Give us longer breaks, give us more smoking time, give us a Kotex machine --

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Do it and I'll shut up.

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: Well, we're gonna do better'n that. We figure the only way to close that mouth is to hand you a promotion. You're rising in the world, honey.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah? How far and for how much?

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: We're gonna put you on as a spot-checker.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It ain't gonna make me any friends.

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: It's gonna make you another dollar and a half an hour. She chews it over. It seems hard to digest.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA . 29
dialogues.text: She is on the floor, clipboard in one hand, stopwatch in the other. She has paused behind LUCIUS WHITE, a black man, and is timing him as he rethreads a loom. When he finishes, she clicks her watch, enters a notation on the board, moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is behind GEORGE HUBBARD, watches as he unstops a spindle. Again, she clicks her watch, marks his time.  el

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She times RAY BUCK completing a run of towels, records his speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, she stands behind her father. Vernon works at th bobbins, doing the job he has done ali his life. He pause only an instant to rub the back of his neck, hurries to recover the tempo. He grins at his daughter over his shoulder, Norma is troubled and unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: How'm I doin! little girl?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You better speed it up, Daddy -- if you can.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: (protesting) I'm goin' as fast as I can.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: They're watching me and they're watching you... The old man grimly bends forward and his hands fly as he pulls bobbins and threads them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, VERNON'S YARD 33
dialogues.text: Craig and Millie in the b.g., climb in and out of a batte cardboard carton, which for them is a train; the SOUNDS o their shouting and laughing rise in the early evening air

dialogues.speaker: VERNON 34
dialogues.text: He. stands on the open back porch at a galvanized tub, scrubbing his hands and face. As he dries off, he uses th towel to whack some of the clinging lint from his shirt and his pants. Norma comes out on the porch; she goes to brush the lint which mats his hair, making him look like a white-haired man of eighty. Vernon stiffly pulls away from her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose you're sore at me.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I don't think you should push your own daddy. Cont.  558 22 34 cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (wrestles With it) It's more money. I need it for my kids.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Well, I don't need it from my kid. And he walks into the house, his back stiff. Norma stands troubled. She calls out to her children, alm absently.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Craig...Millie...get out of Grandma's marigolds. She sits on the top step, hugs her knees, broods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is in progress on the pokey little baseball diamon with weak night lights and a splintered, faded green two-tiered set of bleachers. Bugs wheel endlessly around the lights, tree FROGS CROAK, there is nothing so grand a uniforms -- the two teams play in their work clothes. The scoreboard, broken and sagging, reads: MILLAGEVILLE 15,

dialogues.speaker: PISTON 12,
dialogues.text: There is a sudden thunderclap of wild excitement, bringin everyone to their feet, as the batter powers one far into the darkness of right field, bringing in the two men already on base and tying the score.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS 36
dialogues.text: Norma Rae and Bonnie Mae sit down again with flushed face

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Want something?

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE MAE
dialogues.text: Bring me a hot dog, lotsa relish. Norma climbs over some people and goes down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE STANDS 37
dialogues.text: A hot dog wagon steams; the bugs have concentrated here a well. ‘Norma runs into Reuben at the counter, slathering mustard and relish on his dog. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 37 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: . (to the vendor) QO Two dogs, lotsa relish and no relish. She turns to Reuben.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Enjoying the game?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I like that shortstop. He goes into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's J.C, McAllister. Scouts've been looking at him. Reuben takes a first big bite out of his hot dog and instantly spits it out, spraying dog and bun everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Don't you like it?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: ( Well, it's not Nathan's. In fact, Oo I'm not even sure it's a hot dog. chucks the remainder away in a trash barrel) What do they put in these things?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: A lot of red dye -- and other things you don't want to know about. The CROWD YELLS. Apparently, something interesting has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIS HARPER comes up to the wagon. He is tall, good- looking, fine-boned, educated. When he sees Norma, he stops; there is a sense of constraint between them.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Hello, Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hello, Ellis. oS ELLIS i “ You're looking fine. Cont.  a4 38 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm always fine. I'm a horse.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: You changed your hair.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I let it grow.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: (after a moment's silence) How's Craig?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Lost his front teeth... (voice flattens) »»eIt wouldn't hurt if you came by to see him once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I don't think I should do that, Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Suit yourself -- you always have. The man stands uncomfortably a moment, then quickly turns and walks away. Reuben plunks down a quarter on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'll have an RC Cola. (then to her) Want one?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah. REUBEN. (with another coin) Make it two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinks in hand, they wander around the perimeter of the b field. Cars are parked facing the game, spectators sitvin in them, drinking beer; kids sit or lie atop sedans, watc the action. Young kids on bikes stand, one foot on the pedal, one on the ground. A few young couples sit in the grass, infants crawling not too far from them. Cont.  25 39 Con: As usual, Norma says what she is thinking, without preanb QO out loud, directly.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I climbed in the backseat of his ' Cadillac on a rainy night six years ago, stuck my feet out the window, and got me my little Craig off that Southern gentleman. (dismissively) He's never done anything worthwhile since.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Were you married?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: He didn't bother and I didn't bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first affair, as I recollect it, was with my Hungarian piano teacher. I was playing Smetana and she put her head in my lap. I played the hell out of it. We ended up in the ' bedroom under a Russian icon, and C her husband came home and found us and burst into tears. I went and put my arms around him and said ‘I'm sorry, I'm sorry,' and then we all went into the kitchen and had 4 glass of tea. She looks at him oddly.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Seems like every time you run into me, I'm hassling with some other guy.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: That's what it seems like.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What do you think of me, I wonder?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I think you're too smart for what's happening to you. He lets her think that over -- and she does. They keep walking in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma, with clipboard and st stops to time SONNY WEBSTER, unfathomable young man; the ~ is just beneath it. As she does an extraordinary thing runs to another, starts it, taunting her:

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 26 ho opwatch, makes her rounds. Si. an intense, hidden, surface is calm but frustra zion clicks her watch to start, he -- he leaps away from the loor, calls to her over his shoulder,

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Come on, lady! I'm over here now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to follow him, be loom.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: 4 wildered; he darts to a third

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I'm right over here now! I got the jump on you now! He weaves in and out among the looms, calling, mocking he with a crazy challenge.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I'm behind you now. Yoo-hoo, lady! Why don't you clock me r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘ over here? I'm over here now! he She pelts after him at a dead run, finally grabbing him by the arm, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: " NORMA
dialogues.text: You damn fool, you better cut this out!l The faster you work, the more work they' 11 put on youl

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: What do I care? All I got to do is work! He pulls free and rushes to yet another loom and gets i» going. Norma stops, throwing up her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 Vernon has the children on his’ lap, watching the TELEVIS screen. Leona is across from him in a splint chair, a pho album in her lap. From a cardboard box she selects snapshots and slides them into place. The DOORBELL RINGS, 558 cont.  oO 43 Cont. 27

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'll get it. She goes through the room toward the door. AT THE DOOR 4b Sonny Webster is there when she opens it. She closes it: in his face immediately. Then, bethinking herself, she slowly opens it again. Sonny is quite different now, subdued, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I won't trouble you. I just came to apologize. I know I could've lost you your job today.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You sure went crazy on me.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I know. I got handed divorce papers this morning. I guess I went off my head.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Things can get to you.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Would you come and have a drink with me, to make up for the ruckus and all the bother I put you to? She hesitates a moment, considering it.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I'm Sonny Webster. You used to come in my momma's bakery.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember you now, on the cash register after school. You never made the right change.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I never did too good in math.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (ruminating) Sonny Webster...

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: How about that drink?

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Okay. Wait here. en Re  peaxmsee

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL 45
dialogues.text: She closes the door on him, goes to get her purse and a sweater off a hook in the hall. Her father is right at he heels.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Who's that? I heard a man's voice.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you did, and I'm going out with him.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Where'd you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Just now on the front porch!

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Some Tom, Dick or Harry comes to the door and you got your hat on? No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm over twenty-one -- way over.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Lemme say some names to you, Norma. Buddy Wilson, Ellis Harper, George Benson, a U.S. sailor, a Trailways bus driver -- none of which is lookin' after you, as far as I can see. I got that spot. It's my food, it's my roof,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with all this. Something wrong with the way you try to keep men off me.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: There is nothing wrong with a daddy's love for his little girl. You oughta accept your daddy's love, you oughta rest in it, you oughta shelter in it, you oughta be grateful for it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're loving me to death. She slams out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 ‘Oo

dialogues.speaker: INT, LIVING ROOM 46
dialogues.text: Vernon charges in, stands looking blinded, like an enrage bull. He goes suddenly to grab the snapshots from his wif hands; wildly he begins to rip them in half, one after an flinging them into the air, two jagged halves of Norma's face as a teenager, pieces of Norma on the back of a pony

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: (in horror) Daddy, those are our precious family pictures...

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: They're just scraps now! The children are wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men lined at the bar still grimy from the job, getting th taste of work out of their mouths; drink ends almost ever day and it is not boisterous -- it is serious and dogged, an anodyne. At the back, Norma and Sonny sit in a wooden booth, marke with cigarette burns. Soft drinks, a bucket of ice, and a pottle of bourbon in a brown paper bag stand on the scarr linoleum-topped table; they have made considerable inroad in the liquor. A Dolly Parton RECORD IS PLAYING on the JUKEBOX.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That woman sure can sing...and those words are true, too.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I liked Elvis, myself...

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (high) I'd like to get rich by just opening my mouth and wailing...

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: It don't necessarily make them happy.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (the philosopher) What does, what does, what does? Cont.  30 47 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: A man and a woman is about your best chance.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're a fine one to talk. , Didn't you tell me you took a gun, went slinking along on 1 your belly in the bushes, drew | a@ bead on your wife, aiming to ' blow her head off?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was gonna burn 'em both \ down..-her and her boyfriend... put I couldn't... (pauses ) She was a good person when we went together in school and all. She was a real nice person... put the change that come about in her...it still really amazes me...

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm different than what I was, too. You go through things. She tips herself another consoling glassful. In the proce she looks up and sees someone.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN 48
dialogues.text: He is at the bar, turned on the stool face to face with ORA PURSLEY, in close conference, exhorting him, proselyt ANOTHER ANGLE 4g Norma waves at him from the booth.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hey! You! New York! Reuben, a bit startled, turns and sees her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (gesture is expansive ) Come on over. Sit with us. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 49 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (thwarted) Do we need anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (high) The more the merrier.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BOOTH 50
dialogues.text: as Reuben approaches and stands at the booth.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Reuben, this is Sonny. Sonny, that's Reuben. The two men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Get off your feet. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Working.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: This is a drinking place.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Drunk or sober, I want ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Can I pour you out one? He brandishes the paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'll have some plain seltzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just drinking soda water?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: That's all. Sonny pours him a glass.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You'll feel better'n I will tomorrow morning. Cont. 558  32 50 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Reuben's a union man. Thinks O . he can put a union in the mill.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Ain't ever been one.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Then its hour's come, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: There better be more'n one of you. ‘Cause there's more'n one of them.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: ' There will be.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: These big companies get everything they want. Everything goes to the rich man.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Getting tired of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i When Ido, I just wash it down a) with beer... He drinks. A boozy melancholy enfolds them, heightened by a@ ballad sung by Johnny Cash on the JUKEBOX. It plunges Norma into deeper gloom.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That record was playing on the record player the night they called me up to tell me my husband was killed in a fight in a beer joint.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I knew Buddy Wilson in high school. We had wood shop together.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: He got drunk and broke a beer bottle and got into a fight. Somebody else had a broken beer bottle, too...I remember going to the funeral home. This man comes to the door. I wanted to go in and see Buddy but he C, said he didn't have him prepared, po and he didn't think it would be | 558 a good idea for me to see him. | Cont.  558

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 50 Cont.1 NORMA (Cont.) I really wanted to see him, but Daddy wouldn't let me go in... (shrugs) And that was the end of Buddy, as far as that goes... Each, in his own way, sits quietly considering mortality.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET 51
dialogues.text: The three have come out on the deserted sidewalk. The tav lights go off behind them. Norma and Sonny are carrying a full load.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna drive.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No, I'll drive.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're drunk.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: So're you.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'll drive. He herds them toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben is at the wheel, Norma in the middle, Sonny on the

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, I went out with one man and I'm coming home with two. That oughta surprise my daddy . some.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: He sure watches you close.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: We are close. Lots of times when I was a kid, he'd give in an excuse at the mill so he could stay home and play with me in the snow. He used to drive 250 miles to Crescent Beach to buy me a chicken dinner, take me swimming, tell me jokes. We'd sleep in the back of the car parked on the beach and walk on the sand in the morning. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 52 Cont. NORMA (Cont.) (waggles her fingers) He bought me this ring on my finger... She suddenly turns to address Reuben politely.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Could you stop the car? I'm gonna be sick. Reuben pulls over and stops instantly, getting out and he her out the door.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY ,
dialogues.text: (apologetically, helpless) I can't help, Norma, or I'd give it up, too.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE SIDE OF THE ROAD 53
dialogues.text: Norma is crouched in the bushes, Reuben bent over he:r, n her waist with one hand, her forehead with the other. She straightens at last, wan but recovered.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, that's real ladylike of me...

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I did bedpans one summer at Stuyvesant Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: One of these days I'm gonna put myself all together.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Make it soon. Because one of these days, I'm going to start in on you. Her look says it can't be now. He helps her back to the c

dialogues.speaker: FRONT OF THE MILL 54
dialogues.text: Another work day, the mill hands streaming through the ga Reuben is once again stationed at his post, handing out leaflets. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 35 54 Cont. Norma falls behind her father and mother to take one from She reads it.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I took your advice. I'm down to two syllables.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: One's better. She hands it back to him and goes jauntily into the mill.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FLOOR 55
dialogues.text: As she enters the tremendous weaving room floor, stopwatc clipboard at the ready, she comes face to face with MAVIS PRUITT and gives her a cheery greeting.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hi, Mavis. Mavis gives her a long, cold look, then deliberately turn her back. Norma stares after her, surprised; then turns a goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINETTE ODUM is heading for the looms. Norma hails her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: ‘Morning, Linette. The woman deliberately stops, looks her up and down, from head to toe, and then without a word moves to her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma, disturbed now, goes up to BILLY STETTIN, taking hi place at a loom, and taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hiya, Billy. The man doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy! He busies himself with the spindle, his face grim.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What is this! What the hell is this! Cont.  mrrrrrsss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 57 Cont. NORMA (Cont.) (grabs him by the shirt) Billy! Billy! I'm talking to you. Billy turns to her, flinging her hand off his shirt, and out one word.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY '
dialogues.text: Fink! b He turns away from her. She stands slone, in a steaming r

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, shit! } And without a pause she wheels around and marches toward Tommy Gardner's office.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE 58
dialogues.text: She bangs open the door and, without ceremony, bursts in. Gardner looks up from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Nobody out there's talking to. mel

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: Less talk, more work.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: They're my friends and they're gonna stay my friends! I'm quitting! I'm quitting right here, I'm quitting right now. You're speeding ‘em up and then you're gonna weed 'em out!

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: You knew all that.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, I was greedy and I was dumb and now I'm sorry. You can fire mel

dialogues.speaker: GARDNER
dialogues.text: .No, we won't do that. We'll just put you back in the weaving room, Norma. Your family's been in this mill for a long time. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 37 58 cont. She plunks the instruments of her now-hated trade down on his desk, turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Norma comes to take a spot beside her friend Bonnie Mae Buffum on the shuddering floor. The inexorable work goes on, without end, without pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny drives up in his old Ford and gives one discreet be on his horn. Norma emerges on the front steps; holding ea hand are Millie and Craig. She marches them down to the c

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (firmly) We're all ready.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (it's a bit more than he bargained for) All of you?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: All three of us.

dialogues.speaker: SCNNY
dialogues.text: (with good grace) Well, then, everybody hop in.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Roll the window down if you're hot.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: I wanna sit up front.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, you can't.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Are we there yet?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No, we just started off. (to Sonny) I thought we were going to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: We are. I gotta make a stop first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ol 158

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny's car is at the curb in front of another house, Nor and her children waiting impatiently. After a moment, Sonny emerges, a small girl's hand in his He introduces her.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: This is Alice. She's mine.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Like I always say -- the more the merrier. Alice hops into the back with the boy and.the girl. off they go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids play along the bank, clambering over a tree that spans the water. Norma and Sonny sit on a blanket, remnan of their picnic before them, hugging their knees, at ease with each other.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You're real easy with your kids.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Oh...I yell. I swat ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Youtre a pretty woman.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I wasn't bad at eighteen. But things have slid and slipped...

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You look fine to me.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Keep the lights low and i'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well. I'll take you where it's dark.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (makes a weary wave with her hand) I've been there. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eesve res 39 63 Cont. Sonny is silent a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I don't owe a nickel in this town. I'll eat anything that's put down in front of me. I can fix anything electrical. I'm all right after I've had my first cup of coffee -- I want that bad, though. I got mea new job at the gas station. I'd turn over my paycheck the minute I got it -- that's Friday noon. And I come straight home from work and stay there. ’ (finally turns to look at her) I got me Alice and I'm alone. You got two kids and you're alone. If you could help me maybe I could help you.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: She stares out at the bright setting sun, debating it. Af a moment, she says:

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: ...It's been a long time between A offers.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: She turns and looks at him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, kiss me. And, if that's all right, the rest'll be. He takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: WEAVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Norma and Bonnie work side by side in the hellish din. Bonnie passes her a flyer. Norma unfolds it and reads it:

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Norma shoves the flyer in her pocket and continues workin

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Roscoe says I shouldn't go -- but I'm going. Na! NORMA 18 I'm not asking anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Norma and Bonnie walk up the rickety wooden steps and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are plain wooden walls, plain wooden pews, and a to black assembly. As the only white people, they are at fir a little tentative, as if they were intruding, and they h in the entrance. A large, impressive man, JAMES BROWN, wa them on in with his straw hat. They walk all the way down the front and sit in front of the altar, with its cross, brightly colored picture of Jesus, a jelly glass filled w wild flowers. The people wait in silence, patiently.

dialogues.speaker: CAR 67
dialogues.text: Reuben drives down a winding dirt country road, past dry forests, fields of tobacco plants, row after row of cotto Now and again there is a bleached wooden shack with a tin off which the sun glints. It is a dry, somnolent, empty landscape, hard to unlock, hard to invade. A turn in the road shows Reuben the church up ahead -- an at that instant, his car goes out of control.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR , 68
dialogues.text: He spins the wheel, which is suddenly loose in his hands, slams his foot against the brake again and again, but the is out of control and hurtles wildly in a careening slide leaving the road, bumping across a field, while he contin vainly fighting the steering wheel. The car crashes into pine tree, bursting into flames.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR 69
dialogues.text: The door is jammed and, as he scuttles across to the othe side, the windshield heats and cracks and EXPLODES. Reube hauls himself through the open window, falling to the gro rising quickly and backing away from the heat. Figures come running from the church in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE CAR 70
dialogues.text: Reuben leans panting against a tree as some of the blacks approach. For a moment, everyone stands silently watching the car burn with great gouts of black smoke.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: {to the men) The steering wheel went. The brakes went. Everything went.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Looks like they're startin’ in 58 on you. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i 70 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | oN It's either them or General Motors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | al INT. CHURCH 71 As Reuben steps up to the altar to deliver his speech, he glances at Norma and Bonnie just beneath him. If he is surprised, he makes no sign.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN 72
dialogues.text: He stands in front of the quiet, hopeful, needful people have risked something to be here. He speaks very simply.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: On October 4, 1970, my grandfather, Isaac Abraham Warshovsky, aged 87, died in his sleep in New York City. On the following Friday morning, his funeral was held. My mother and father attended, my two. uncles from Brooklyn attended, my Aunt Minnie came up from Florida. Also present were 862 members of The Amalgamated Clothing Workers and The Cloth, Hat and Cap Makers' Union. Also members of his family. C In death as in life, they stood CO at his side. They had fought battles with him, bound the wounds of battle with him, had earned bread together and had broken it together. When they spoke, they spoke in one voice, and they were heard. They were black, they were white, they were Irish, they were Polish, they were Catholic, they were Jews, they were one. That's what a union is: one. ! (pauses) Ladies and gentlemen, the textile industry, in which you are spending your lives and your substance, and in which your children and their children will spend their lives and substance, is the only industry in the whole length and breadth of the United States of America that is not unionized. Therefore, they are free to exploit you, to cheat you, to lie to you, and to take away what is rightfully yours -- val . Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4e 72 Cont. REUBEN (Cont.) “) your health, a decent wage, a fit place to work. I would urge you to stop them by coming down to room 207 at the Golden Cherry Motel, \ to pick up a union card and sign \ it. ! (pauses again) ! It comes from the Bible -- according to the tribes of your fathers, ye shall inherit. It comes from Reuben Warshovsky -- ' not unless you make it happen. i é He stops talking. The people have listened.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE CHURCH 73
dialogues.text: People are coming up to Reuben to shake his hand, to murm words of appreciation. Bonnie Mae approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Roscoe should've come. He should've heard you.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Bring him next time. oS BONNIE (agreeing) If I have to drag him. It is Norma's turn next. She stands in front of him with slight grin.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You preach pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: When are you going to join up?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Me? Who's got the time? I got my hands full as is.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (flat) Make the time. Sleep less. If I don't get some help, it's kaput, finished, I'm out of town -- and you got nothing. 358

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away from her-and shakes hands with James Brown.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate any help you can give me. That's licking stamps, stuffing envelopes, typing with two fingers -- anything.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I'll show up. Norma stands to the side, a little baffled, frustrated, | uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belonging to the Justice of the Peace, stuffed with batte mohair furniture and family pictures. The wedding in prog is not overly festive: Norma holds a rather bedraggled little bouquet, but she is still a bird of plumage in her bright print dress. Once her mind is made up, she sweeps everything before her. The others, Sonny beside her, Bonnie Mae and Roscoe as witnesses, are slightly uncomfor in unaccustomed finery.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE OF THE PEACE
dialogues.text: .«..and, with the powers that the State of Georgia vests in me, I now pronounce you man and wife. And mother over there has a glass of homemade wine for us -- picked the berries myself last summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn to the little table on which his WIFE has prepared six tumblers and a bottle of red wine. Sonny raises his glass in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: To my wife, Norma -- and I sure hope I can keep up with her. Roscoe laughs loudly and claps him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: PITCHER TT
dialogues.text: The wedding bouquet has been stuck in a pitcher standing @ bureau.
Se ee 558

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny sits on the edge of the bed in his pajama bottoms, removing the price tag from the top. He then pulls it ove his head, smooths back his hair, sits waiting. Norma emer from the bathroom in a nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hot water tap's leaking in there.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY 1
dialogues.text: Needs a washer. , (then) That sure is a pretty nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Look at it quick, ‘cause I'm going to take it off. She comes and sits beside him on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You happy?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, I got another chance to be. They are interrupted by a hideous SOUND, the LOUD BLASTIN a CAR HORN. It is no mere tapping of a horn; it is a continuous, insistent, nerve-scraping blare, beginning ve close, as though the car were right under their window, t gradually receding as the car drives away; finally ceasin altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Norma. leans to her husband. They go into each other's for a long embrace. The RACKET RESUMES, more emphatic than before, severing t intimacy. The CAR HORN is a raucous, jarring howl, contin for a long, long moment directly under their window. Norm sits back tensely, alerted. Again, the assault begins to DIMINISH, as the car cruises slowly away. It becomes a WA in the distance and again DISAPPEARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny draws her fiercely into his arms, pulls her down on the bed, throws the covers over then. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 80 Cont. They begin to make love. The HORN STARTS AGAIN. The maniacal shivaree fills the night; it is a relentless intrusion, a relentless invasio Norma suddenly flings back the covers, snatches up a robe flings it around her and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands on the porch, yelling at the top of her voice the car that is slowly cruising away, HORN STILL BLATANT.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Daddy, I know it's youl I know it's youl Quit itl Leave me alonel Quit messing with mel Go homel There's only room for two in that bed in there! The car goes around a corner and the SOUND of the HORN EB The street is suddenly very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma returns to Sonny, throwing the robe aside. She is defiant, angry, agitated. She snaps off the light, gets b into bed. But they lie still, tense, waiting for the inexorable return. The moments pass. The night is peacefu Slowly Norma relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's all right now. She turns to her husband, goes into his arms. A long mome passes, then the light. goes on. Sonny sits up in bed, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, honey, I can't do nothing. Norma turns out the light again. In the dark, her VOICE i HEARD, determined.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yes, you canl The other presence in the room is to be fended off.  oO 558

dialogues.speaker: THREE BOSSMEN 83
dialogues.text: Three very grim, hard-faced men stand at the gate as the morning shift passes them: RICK LUJAN, DAN PETERS, WOODROW BOWZER. The mood is one of confrontation, testy, edgy, muscular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have long to wait. Reuben appears, dressed in tennis shoes, jeans and a golf slicker, a large TWUA butt on his chest. He is gulping his breakfast en route, a : doughnut and a paper cup of coffee. ' He steps up to the three men with a manner that is cool, and peremptory.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm here, and I'm ready to look at your plant. The three men just stand immobile, presenting a formidabl barrier.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: The federal government of the United States, brothers, in Federal Court Order Number 7778, states the following: the union has the right to inspect every bulletin board in the mills at least once a week, to verify in person that its notices are not being stripped off. He is finished with the coffee and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You got a trash can? Bowzer indicates one nearby with his granite jaw. Reuben. tosses the empty cup into it.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Keep America beautiful. They flank him and escort him inside.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MILL 85
dialogues.text: “ The DIN is at full pitch, as always. LEROY MASON is wai for them. He dispenses with greetings and hands Reuben a of earmuffs. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 Cont. Reuben looks around, notes that they are not standard iss hands them back.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I think I'll just keep my ears open, friend. It is necessary for voices to be raised in order to be he above the NOISE; Mason hears him. He turns abruptly and begins the progress. They march, prison-style, Mason in front, Reuben in the center, the three bossmen bringing u rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mason goes at quick-step, taking off like a striped ape. Reuben lets him go. After fifty feet, a hundred, Mason st turns, sees that Reuben is not with him, and storms back.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Am I going too quick for you or something?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Look, man, I don't do high port. I did my running when iL was in the Marine Corps. I'm not in the Marine Corps now.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Well, if you're not in shape, we'll slow down...

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'd appreciate that. Let's just saunter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line of march begins again and Reuben swerves right o it. He approaches JED BUFFUM at a loom, taking a pad and pencil out of his shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Good morning. I'm Reuben Warshovsky of the Textile Workers! Union of America. What's your name, brother? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFUM
dialogues.text: (uneasily) O Buffun.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: How long you worked here, Mr. Buffum?

dialogues.speaker: BUFFUM
dialogues.text: 1 Twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Like your job?

dialogues.speaker: BUFFUM
dialogues.text: Like to keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cohort of bossmen surrounds him again.

dialogues.speaker: BOWZER
dialogues.text: Warshovsky, you're interfering with the work, and the court order says you can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OC Well, then, brother, let's SF both keep to the letter of the law.

dialogues.speaker: BOWZER
dialogues.text: (mildly) I don't have no kike brother.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I don't think you meant to use that word.

dialogues.speaker: BOWZER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I did.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Shit, now I gotta stop and get into a fight. Mason steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: The bulletin board is right over there. The words separate the two antagonists. Reuben turns and 4 strides directly to it.  558

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BULLETIN BOARD 89
dialogues.text: He stands with his hands in his back pockets, rocking bac and forth on his heels, looking at’ the board. The others up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Somebody's looking to get into a carpool...somebody wants to sell a bassett pup +-.and you can pick pecans at forty cents a bushel at Selma Landing... pauses ) Only thing missing is my notice.

dialogues.speaker: LUJAN
dialogues.text: It's there.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I don't see it. The man points up high, to the very top of the board. Reuben's eyes follow his gesture.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Wilt Chamberlain on stilts could read it, maybe. (voice hardens) Put it at eye level, fuckers, where everybody can read it. One or two of the bossmen bridle at the epithet but Mason maintains order.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: We'll take note of your request.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (spreads his hands ) Why do you guys try this horseshit? Now I got to go to the phone and call my lawyers and get 'em on your ass. It's childish. (turns to them) Where's the pay phone and who's got two nickels? Cont.  558

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: (to the others, quietly) Bring it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Lujan scrapes a chair over, heaves his bulk up on it, out the thumbtacks while the other men stand watching, an puts it in a lower and more prominent position. Reuben steps forward to read the notice carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAM BOLEN hurries over, wheezing hard and full of self- importance.

dialogues.speaker: BOLEN
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to read the damn thing!

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: No union organizer, not even a@ Known union member, has been inside the fences or walls of this factory in more than ten years. I'm reading it.

dialogues.speaker: BOLEN
dialogues.text: Read fast.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: While I'm reading this, tell you what -- you go read the court order that says any agent of this company can be held in contempt. You're messing with a contempt citation, and if you're hot for jail just keep it up.

dialogues.speaker: BOLEN
dialogues.text: (backing off) I don't violate no laws.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Baby, you're violating the law now.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Can we finish this? Cont. 90 gl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wees ee . ct nooeeeese

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 91 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Where's the other board?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: At the other entrance.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The contingent turns and marches across the length of the weaving room, over the bucking floor, through the snowsto lint, past workers who are alerted to his presence there, turn over their shoulders to watch him, who exchange a fu word. Reuben takes it all in; more than that, he draws attention to himself:

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Hello, there...how are you this morning?...Warshovsky of the TWUA...morning, ma'am, Reuben Warshovsky, TWUA... hello there, sir. I'ma union organizer, Dixie Motel downtown, door's always open... Oo NORMA 93 Among those he passes is Norma. They exchange an especial significant look. THE MARCH gl The company phalanx grows larger as they go, with each addition taller and broader than Reuben.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BULLETIN BOARD 95
dialogues.text: There are boxes and bolts of cloth arranged and stacked i such a way as to completely block the board. Confronted with the contempt the company has for its work force, the obvious manipulation he sees, he stands thoughtfully a moment. It is beyond anger or outburst.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You know, gentlemen, your average working man isn't stupid -- he just gets tired. (pauses ) - Move that shit out of there. LG Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 95 Cont. No one speaks. The bossmen form a semicircle behind Reube He is backed up to the bulletin board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Brown and TWO OTHER BLACK MILL HANDS walk out betwe the row of boxes. They stop and look. Mason looks at the black men, then at his assistants.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Move the stuff. i The black men wrestle the boxes and bolts away, clearing board. : NORMA oT watching. Interested, engrossed, making up her mind.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN'S MOTEL ROOM 98
dialogues.text: It is a shambles of abandoned meals, cartons, filing cabi empty Coke bottles, dirty towels, shucked clothes, union applications, battered typewriter, just-washed T-shirts hanging, dripping, on the floor from chairs and light fix Reuben is forking cole slaw out of a carton as he studies brief. ‘There is a KNOCK. He opens the door to Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You busy?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Eating my dinner.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ROOM 99
dialogues.text: She makes a slow turn, taking in the disorder.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Don't they ever clean up in here? Cont. 558

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I don't want 'em messing with my papers. I know where everything is. She seems unready to state her purpose. She ambles around room, coming to rest before Dorothy again.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You heard from Dorothy Finkelstein?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. She sent me a box of onion bagels. They're ina drawer somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I smell 'em. She picks up the picture idly, turns it this way and that

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I went to beauty school once. I could fix that hair for her.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: She's got it under a babushka most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (musing) I could sit on my hair when I was fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: , REUBEN
dialogues.text: (pointedly ) Now you sit on your hands. She gives him a long, level look.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: If I joined up with you, would I lose my job?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: No way! You can wear a union button as big as a frisbee when you go to work. You can talk union to any mill hand who wants to listen, as long as it's during a break. You can take union pamphlets to the mill and pass ‘em along -- and there's not 2 goddam thing they can do to touch you. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 99 Cont.2

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: CO Well...I was never even in LA the Girl Scouts -- but I'll go along with you.

dialogues.speaker: ' REUBEN '
dialogues.text: ' (pleased) ' You're the fish I wanted ' to hook.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: | (pauses ) Well...now you got me, what're you gonna do with me? He is busy at the desk, scrabbling for application papers

dialogues.speaker: ' REUBEN '
dialogues.text: , Make a mensch out of you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: ) There's that lingo again.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It means somebody who goes to visit the Old People's Home { instead of playing golf on Saturday morning. Somebody who pays the rent for a widow. » Somebody who puts a dollar in a@ blind man's cup for a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (confident of her worth) I'd do that.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: But would you take the pencil?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Surel I paid for it, didn't I? He waggles his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Between logic and charity falls a shadow. We could debate it all night. (shoves a blue card toward her) Sign. (3 Cont. i 558

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 ct ee ee oe wre cRNA ET tw 55 99 Cont.2 She signs her name with a flourish. He picks up the card studies it.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Norma Rae Webster. Why does everybody around here have three names? He puts her card on top of the pile.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT HALL 100
dialogues.text: Norma enters, burdened with two large bags of groceries a as she wrestles with the bags at the door and tries to ge door shut with her foot, one splits and potatoes tumble o and roll across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Damn! I told 'em to double bag itl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she is on the floor, trying to retrieve the spilled groceries, Sonny comes hastily to kneel beside her; over shoulder, in the living room, she sees a strange woman.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Just listen. If you didn't make the bed this morning, go do itl He pushes the bag back in her arms and returns to the liv room. Norma starts for the kitchen, can't contain herself follows him into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plunks down the bags and faces the lady firmly.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Sonny can't say no. I don't want no Tupperware, no magazine subscriptions, no calf-bound Bible! Cont.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: This is Missus Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mrs. Webster. I'm from the state adoption agency.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (in alarm) I got no kids up for adoption herel

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Mr. Webster has petitioned to adopt your son, Craig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma sinks back into a chair. She is moved.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You sure kept it to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I was gonna surprise you.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, I am. ghe is astonished into quiet and sits listening to the WO.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Shall we go on? You have a child of your own?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yes, that's Alice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Do you feel you'd be closer to your own child than to Craig?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, I don't. They'd be treated the same in everything.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Do you think that you might at any time come to resent the fact that the boy is illegitimate.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't. Cont. Cont. other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c™ Wd 558

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 103 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Wny do you want to do this, Mr. Webster? yi Sonny thinks about it a moment. Words don't come easily t him, but he knows why he wants to do it.
