dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: If I'm gonna pay for the boy's education, and feed him and buy him his clothes, I'm gonna have @ say-so in what he does. I want better for my kids than what a. He suddenly raises his head and sniffs the air. Then he l up and out of his chair and bolts from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Millie is doubled over in gleeful laughter as Craig runs place to place in the yard, striking large kitchen matche igniting the weeds. Already a patch or two are burning ve nicely. Sonny runs up to Craig, scoops him up and gives him a hea whack across the buttocks. The child wails in outrage. So raises his hand again -- and then holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women have come out on the porch. Sonny shouts ac the yard at Mrs. Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You might as well see it, ‘cause it's gonna happen when he deserves it! And he's got it coming, right this minutet He gives the boy another whack, drops him, runs for the g hose and begins to spray the flames:

dialogues.speaker: LUNCHROOM . 106
dialogues.text: Norma, wearing a huge TWUA button, attempts to enlist WAYNE BILLINGS over their coffee break. Booze and extra poundage are fast blurring his boyish good looks.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (holding a button out) Come on, Wayne, lemme pin it on you. ataae cover that gravy spot on your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: What do I get if I do? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 106 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You get nothing if you don't. Haven't you enough of that?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You and me used to heat up that N.C.O. Club down at the base. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Bygone days.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Well, pin it on me for bygone days, then.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Stand still. She pins the large button on hin.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Think we'll ever see that club again, Norma, honey? :

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Take your wife -- she doesn't get out much. She walks out quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FLOOR 107
dialogues.text: Lujan, the bossman, bars her way.

dialogues.speaker: LUJAN
dialogues.text: Looks like you strayed off the reservation, Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: LUJAN
dialogues.text: You got your own coffee machine at your end. ‘

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I ain't got a water fountain at my end, and I gotta cool my coffee down before I drink it.

dialogues.speaker: LUJAN
dialogues.text: (flatly) You cool everything down. She swings her hips as she walks away from him. 558

dialogues.speaker: INT, CHURCH 108
dialogues.text: The white church is a bit larger, in somewhat better repair than Chockoyotte. The REVEREND WAYNE HUBBARD, 'though minister to this flock, does its menial as well as its spiritual work, and with hammer and nails is busy mending the lectern as Norma comes in. .

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: You caught me in my shirtsleeves, Norma,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Reverend.

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: Maybe we could have some flowers out of your yard for Sunday, Norma. I got spider mite eating up everything. Can I help you with something?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: How long have I been coming to this church, Reverend?

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: Since you were a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's right. I accepted Christ when I was six years old. Would you call me a good Christian?

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: With a lapse or two, I'd say so.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Would you call yourself a good Christian?

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: That's for the Lord to say.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I want this church for a union meeting next Saturday afternoon. That's blacks and whites, sitting together. He stops his work and puts down his hammer,

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: This is a house of God. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's what I'm waiting to see -- if it is or it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: You're coming close to blasphemy, Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I've come here and I've said that I've sinned and I've done wrong and I'm sorry and I want God to forgive me. Now I want to see what this church stands for. I want to see if you'll stand up in that pulpit and say there should be justice, there should be union, if you're oppressed, fight back, if you're smitten, rise up -- and the Lord'll be on your side. If you don't do that, I say there's nothing in this church that's any good to me and I'll leave it flat.

dialogues.speaker: HUBBARD
dialogues.text: We'll miss your voice in the choir, Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You'll hear it raised up someplace else. And she turns on her heel and walks out on him.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY'S HOUSE 109
dialogues.text: Norma pulls up to the curb behind Reuben's car, parks and gets out, four black men and one white emerging with her. She says to them:

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You all go in and sit down. I'll be right there. Then she turns purposefully and walks directly across the street. NORMA AND DAN PETERS lio Peters stands on the walk to his house, making an elabora ritual of filling a pipe, tamping it down, sucking on it, as he studies the activity in front of him, Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 110 Cont. His small boy TYLER rocks on a swing on the porch behind him, Norma comes up to the man,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: We're holding a meeting at my house, Dane Union business and then lemonade and cookies. Gingersnaps. I'11 roll up the front shade so you can see right in. Washed. my windows Saturday so you shouldn't have ‘any trouble. Norma sails back across the street to her house. AT HER DOOR lil Sonny is waiting for her, perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You're going too far now, Norma. This here is where we live.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: ‘How'm I going too far?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Bunch of black men in there... you're gonna get us in a lot of trouble. :

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I never had any trouble with black men, Only trouble I ever had in my life was with white men. She goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LIVING ROOM 112
dialogues.text: Reuben is already present, together. with another handful of mill hands, black and white. Among those who have come are James Brown, Lucius White, Bonnie Mae and Roscoe, Mavis Pruitt. They are seated on the sofa and on wooden chairs lined around in a circle. <A few men stand against the wall, holding their caps in their hands. Cont.  hoy 558

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 112 Cont. There is no sense of being ill at ease; only of gravity, fatigue, need. Reuben speaks.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I remember some of you from the Chockoyotte Church...I did all the talking that day, I'd like you to talk now. There is silence for a moment, HENRY PROUTY, an old man, looks around the circle, clears his throat, .

dialogues.speaker: ABNER SACKS
dialogues.text: A man's work should be a man's work -- not a term in jail.

dialogues.speaker: WOODROW THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I got a cousin on the chain gang, says I don't work as hard as you do. A work-worn WOMAN smooths the folds in her lap, reluctant to speak, But she does so,

dialogues.speaker: VELMA STACKHOUSE
dialogues.text: Excuse me for saying this with men folks here, but if I get my menstrual cramps, which come pretty hard, they won't lemme sit down on my job.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE PICKENS
dialogues.text: They say you gotta keep to your feet unless you bring a note from the doctor. We wouldn't say we was sick if we wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES BROWN
dialogues.text: I look at a brick wall all day. Used to be a window there but they come and bricked it up to give us the feeling we're shut in. We control your soul, brother and sister, for all this period -- and beware! That's what they're saying with that wall. A COUCH SPRING TWANGS and a coil of wire pokes up, causin Louise Pickens to jump to her feet. Norma is apologetic. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 “NORMA The kids are jumping on it all the time. (brings a chair) Sit here.

dialogues.speaker: RAY TOWNER
dialogues.text: All through the mill they got this cotton dust and lint that fills up the air. (pauses slightly) I got brown lung. Cough all night and my wife doesn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LINETTE ODUM
dialogues.text: My husband Averill died of brown lung two months ago. His children're going to grow up without knowing him. I got all his clothes if someone could use 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Norma and Reuben are alone, She has brewed a pot of coffee. He is.hunched over his cup, dissatisfied.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'm not getting the message across. Fifteen people out of eleven hundred.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're an outsider. Down here things take time. This isn't no New York, where you grab a taxi and grab your hat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are interrupted by the appearance of a very sleepy Millie in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE
dialogues.text: Momma, Craig is wetting the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (as she goes) I told him not to drink Coke before he goes to sleep. Reuben sits @ moment, then rises to foliow her.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY 115
dialogues.text: He wanders after her, still sipping from his cup. He continues talking to her through the open door to the bathroom, where she kneels and supports a still sleeping Craig on the toilet. A little TINKLING SOUND accompanies their talk.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: We've got to get this thing moving. It's bogging down on me.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Buy a jug of corn whiskey and pick me up on Saturday. We'll hit the back roads. (looks down) Finished, honey? Craig nods once and his head falls to his chest. She hoists him off the toilet, pulls up his pajamas, lifts him in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: A. A COUNTRY STORE
dialogues.text: on the outskirts of town, Saturday leisure for half a dozen men in work clothes from.the mill consists of sitting or squatting on the gallery of the store with pocketknives and chunks of wood. Reuben puts his foot up on the porch while Norma takes an RC Cola out of the ice chest and cools down. “In a gesture calculated to make him one of them, Reuben takes out a penknife, pries open a blade and begins to whittle as he addresses the men in dumb-show. Chips fly off his stick as he becomes evermore impassioned, The men listen impassively. Before he knows it, he has whittled his stick down to a toothpick, which snaps in his hands. Norma laughs.

dialogues.speaker: B. A CREEK
dialogues.text: A baptism is taking place, people standing knee-high in a little creek. A virginal girl in a white robe, frightened and transported, is tipped backward and submerged. She is lifted, hair streaming, gasping, drenched. A hand reaches INTO the SHOT --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- As Norma leans forward to press a blue union card into the girl's outflung hand. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tb

dialogues.speaker: D. AN EATING STAND
dialogues.text: A crude, misspelled, hand-lettered sign reads: "PIG

dialogues.speaker: PIG'S FEET."
dialogues.text: Reuben sets himself a little grimly, reaches around his neck to remove the chain with the large Mogen Navid on it, and tucks in manfully as Norma distributes leaflets to the men clustered around.

dialogues.speaker: E. A YARD
dialogues.text: A mill worker keeps chickens in a roost and a single dairy cowe As Reuben stands in close and serious talk with the man, the cow wanders up. Reuben puts a hand on its rump and shoves it -- the cow bellows, wheels and shits as it lumbers away -- and Reuben is splattered from chin to boots. Norma offers a laconic comment.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's only grass and water, Reuben... AT A SWIMMING HOLE lel A little river running through sand and clay, the grass spotted with blue and white daisies, sheltered by a row of sedge. The sun is high, the air still, and Reuben is in the water, rolling and snorting, naked, content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma is downstream a little on the bank, vigorously scrubbing his soiled clothes. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: This is where we used to swim when we were kids. We'd hookey off from school, come down here, shuck our clothes and jump in,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: The only water I ever saw when I was a kid was when we opened a fire hydrant on 110th Street with a monkey wrench, He floats on his back, very much at peace with the world.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Ahh...this is the life, Cont.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 66 122 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's just a mudhole.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It's cooling off my mosquito bites.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA , 123
dialogues.text: She wrings out the wet jeans and then spreads them on a rock,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's as clean as they're gonna get. . Then she leans back on her heels, wipes the sweat from he face.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: God, it's hot...I'm coming in. She gets up and begins to shed her clothes matter-of-fact

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN 124
dialogues.text: He swims about lazily, enjoying himself, When he turns again, Norma is in the water near him.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN AND NORMA 125
dialogues.text: They tread water in place, hardly rippling the surface, quiet, cooling down.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: There used to be a farmer around here with a B-B gun. I hope he's moved.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: There's something flicking around my toes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Minnows, They won't hurt you, (grins a little) You're sure a fish out of water down here, aren't you? Cont.  558 67 125 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It's not exactly my native habitat.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What would you do at home on a day like this?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Play handball at the YMHA. Go ' see Aida at the Met. Eat Chinese. Get in a poker game. Hit the sack.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I've been two places in my life. Millageville and Piston.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: New York's a great town. Got a great zoo, jazz joints, terrific food, theater, beautiful women...

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're homesick, Reuben.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. (pauses) You get up on @ fall morning, look out over the park, the tops of the trees are red. You see a pretty girl with a long scarf tied around her neck, long legs, long hair, You know before the day's over, you're going to meet that girl. About five o'clock, when everybody starts rushing for home, when the streets are jammed, you're turning into an Irish bar, and she'll be there. You'll sit ata little table with your knees touching, drinking an over-priced martini, loquacious, tumescent, terrific. Then you eat a garlicky Italian dinner, get hustled on Madison Avenue for a buck, kiss her good night and lose her phone number,.-eNew York, What a townec. Cont.  68 125 Cent

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'll never get there,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I was born poor, I'll stay poor, I'll probably die poor. She submerges, reappears, her hair streaming; she brushes it back from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You got a skinny build.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Sonny works out with weights.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I tried that. Dropped 'em and broke my foot.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to worry. You got a head on you, and you use it. She turns and climbs out of the water, picks up her shirt acd begins toweling off. He follows. They stand sice ty side, naked, backs to the CAMERA, drying themselves.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SONNY'S BEDROOM 126
dialogues.text: Sonny, in bed, groans and wakes to the SOUND of his wifs VOICE, coming from the kitchen. He rears up on an elbow, squints with one eye at the bedside clock -~ it is past eleven. He is irritated at not finding her beside him -- suddenly he throws back the covers and heads for her.

dialogues.speaker: INT, KITCHEN 127
dialogues.text: Norma is at the phone, a long checklist of names on aj, 4 beside, most of them already crossed off. She is wearing glasses, a baggy old. sweater, a pencil in her disordered hair. cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 127 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: / NORMA
dialogues.text: «eeSure, I know why we got @ bad connection -- they probably got a tap on my phone. Hey, youl You listening? This is - Norma Rae Webster, talking union to Henry Willis. Sonny, rumpled, aggrieved, wearing shorts, appears in the doorway and stands, watching his wife.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm on tonight and every night, no commercials, same old story, union, union, union, Tell your bossman to tape me and you can go on home to your wife and kids. (then) Henry, you still there? The line BUZZES in her ear, the connection broken.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Damn! She hangs up angrily, sits fuming a moment, then yanks ou the pencil, puts a question mark after Henry's name, fina becomes aware of her husband: in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Sonny speaks shortly.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You ain't getting any sleep and I ain't getting any sleep and we both gotta go ‘to work in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I got a hundred names to call here.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: That gonna go on our phone pill?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It'll come out of my paycheck, how's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't answer, pads past her to the refrigerator, pours a glass of cold milk, takes a mouthful, makes a face, sloshes the rest into the sink,

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: This milk's sour.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I didn't get to the market.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (goading) . You didn't get to the market and you didn't get to the washing and you didn't get to the kids and you didn't get to me.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (with icy calm) Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (raging on) We're eating them frozen TV dinners, the kids are going around in dirty jeans, and I'm going without altogether!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma pushes back from the table, making a very large show of it,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Okay. You want cooking? You got cooking. There is a tremendous clatter as she yanks open cupboard doors and pots tumble out in every direction, strewn by the fury of her gesture. She slams one on the stove, grab a hunk of meat and some cabbage from the refrigerator, throws the meat into the pot, adds water, whacks the cabb in half, tosses that in as well, bangs the lid on top of Cont.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 558 71 130 Cont. She whirls on Sonny again.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You want laundry? You got laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens a bin stuffed to the brim with dirty clothes. She hauls out a huge armload, dumps it in the sink, runs the tap water, pours liquid soap over it. She faces Sonny. once more,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You want ironing? You got ironing! She snatches up a shirt out of a basket of unironed clothes, pulls open a cupboard door, wrestles out the ironing board, kicks it vehemently into an upright positi grabs an iron, jams it into a plug. She spreads out the shirt, spits on her finger and tests the iron's heat, begins making furious swipes. Over her shoulder she hurls a final question at Sonny:

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You wanna make love? Get behind me and lift my skirt and we'll make lovel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Sonny stands looking at her, half-admiring, certainly defeated.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Norma, Norma...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBIN ROOM 133
dialogues.text: During break time, Norma passes among the mill hands with a sheaf of leaflets, handing them out. She comes suddenly face-to-face with her father. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 133 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Well, I don't bump into you much these days.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: About the same.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You color's bad. Have you been drinking?

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: Oh, I take a-thimbleful or so.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's not good for you.

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: What's the difference, honey? I'm beginning to wonder when I lie down if I'm gonna get up.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Don't talk old to me, I don't like it. She embraces him fiercely, touched by a strange forebodin

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: One of these nights I'm gonna come by and take you to a grand dinner... She nods and leaves him, weaving through the crowd of mill hands until she is out of sight.  558 73

dialogues.speaker: INT, MOTEL ROOM 134
dialogues.text: It is late. Reuben sits with his legs on the desk, studyi briefs; Norma is at a typewriter at another desk, pecking away with two fingers. She pauses to erase, pecks again, makes another mistake, erases again, pulls the paper out, crumples it up and throws it down. She yawns widely.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (without looking up) James,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: He went home an hour ago. He grunts, goes back to his reading.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I oughta be going home. She gets up, rubs her back, goes to the open window, gets deep breath of air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she turns back, she notes that a new picture of Dorothy Finkelstein has arrived. She goes to it idly.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: How's Dorothy? .

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (absorbed in his reading) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I see you got another picture.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: My mother sent it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I bet she gets along with your mother. He finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? My mother loves her. She's a lawyer, she's Jewish, she's a lefto, and she's a great cook. What the hell else could she want? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 135 Cont. She puts the picture down, stares at it a moment longer. seems a little wistful.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: How'd she get to be so smart?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Books. xX He rummages in one of half a dozen brown paper bags, look for food, comes up with a banana, peels it, eats it voraciously. x Another bag yields a final can of beer. He pulls the tab, holds it out while it foams, drinks deeply.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Dinner. A banana and beer. (goes back to the subject) Books! You read 'em under the covers with a flashlight, you read 'em down in the subway, you put ‘em in your lunch pail, you take 'em to the bathroom and read 'em on the toilet. ‘It's the only way up -- it's the only way out. (burps and thumps his chest) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanders past the row of books he has strewn about, pi one up at random.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Who's Dylan Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: A poet, a drunk, a genius. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: ~136 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What does he write about?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Love, sex, death, and other matters of consequence.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Is he hard to read?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Then why should I bother?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: ‘Cause he's got something to say. xX

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'll try him. Hell, there's nothing but reruns on television.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Don't eat while you reads I can't stand egg yolk on my pooks. She stands riffling through the pages.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBIN ROOM 137
dialogues.text: In the thundering weave section, amidst the DIN and the flying lint, a spot-checker stops behind Vernon, working down a row of pumping bobbins. The man shakes his shoulde shouts in his ear, indicating that he should speed up. Vernon's hands fly, he works at top speed; sweating with exertion.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHURCH 138
dialogues.text: Reuben opens the door to the Chockoyotte Church and enter

dialogues.speaker: INT, CHURCH 139
dialogues.text: It is empty. A kitten has gotten in and picks its way alo the altar, pausing to lift its head and stare at the intruder. Baffled, Reuben sits down in a pew at the back and waits. cause, a man, and a cat.  76

dialogues.speaker: LATTING HOUSE 140
dialogues.text: Reuben pulls up in front of a ramshackle home, its paint worn down to grey board, a step or two broken, the porch listing, an abandoned mattress falling apart in the yard. He knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Warren Latting opens the door, The man is still work stained from his day at the mill, hollow-eyed, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Nobody showed at the meeting today. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: They got us on a stretch-out. Put us on a three-day week. Twice as much work and half the pay. On accout of you. You just stand there a minute. ANOTHER ANGLE 14e He disappears, leaving Reuben to cool his heels on the pe In a moment he is back with a steaming pot in his hand. H lifts the lid.

dialogues.speaker: WARREN
dialogues.text: There's six turnips and two quarts of water in there, Supper for seven people. Go sell your union someplace else, He kicks the door shut in Reuben's face, Reuben explodes; the street fighter in him comes out. He pounds on the dec with his fist until it threatens to give away on its rott hinges and shouts at the top of his voice,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Warren, don't slam the fucking door on me! I'm trying to get you power!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the house on either side, startled faces appear at the windows to glimpse the disturber of the peace.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE OFFICE 144
dialogues.text: Reuben is pawing through a large stack of the blue cards hard won. Norma, James Brown and Lucius White watch him. is still on the nervous edge of energy, tense, temperish, combative. Cont.  © 77 . 144 cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Somebody gets the measles, everybody gets the measles.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Maybe they was too tired to come, Everybody's pretty beat out, working so hard.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You can include me!

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: While we been planning, they been planning. This stretch- out's just the first of what they can hit us with.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: They got away from us, we gotta get 'em back, Walk in a bunch. Show 'em we're solid. (gently) Come on, Reuben, But Reuben sits with his head in his hands. Norma needles him,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Reuben? You running out of gas?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I need to go to a concert, I need an Italian movie. I need some chopped herring.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I could try making you some of that chicken soup and matza dumplings...

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (crossly) Balls! Balls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spreads the cards out.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: All right. Let's get a count on how many we got. Everybody grab a handful. “558 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 78 145 Cont. They each pick up a group of cards. Norma looks at the fi one strangely.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Who's this Billy Joe Hawkins? I never heard of him. James has found one that puzzles him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I got Lindsay Perkins here. He died last year.
Lucius has discovered an odd one.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIUS
dialogues.text: Blayden. He moved his family 1 to Jackson...

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Josh Little, Jr. There ain't no Josh ‘ittle, Jr. in that 5 factory... Reuben begins flipping cards, barking out names.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Ab Harris, Herman Burk, Ardean Miller, Frank Dorn, Dan Decker, Wiley Bains... He looks up at the others. James Brown shakes his head emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No, sir. Those fellows don't work at our plant.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Those names are dummies. (pauses) Somebody wants you to think you got more members than you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stressful moment follows, in which Reuben looks around thoughtfully at his three helpers, ‘Now he has to face th possibility that he has been infiltrated. Outside there is a SQUEAL of BRAKES, a car skidding to a  0 558 79

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE MOTEL 147
dialogues.text: Wayne Billings swings jauntily out of a station wagon tha has been turned into a union float: it is plastered with banners and pennants » U.S. flags front and back and a la sign on top saying, "I'M FOR TWUA."

dialogues.speaker: INT, MOTEL 148
dialogues.text: As Wayne enters, he finds four impassive faces regarding coolly. He drops an impressive-looking batch of cards dow on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's some more bodies for you. Reuben flips one over to James, who glances at it briefly

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Bodies is right, This one's been in the boneyard for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben rises. There is suddenly an impending sense of violence in the closely-packed little room,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I don't want to make a mess of you here, because I eat and sleep here. He throws the false cards into his face. Wayne's mouth cp and closes, opens and closes again. He looks from one tc other; all four are clenched against him. He suddenly gce beserk, He stomps out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MOTEL 150
dialogues.text: He runs to the station wagon, a bull on a rampage, strips huge sign off the’ top and starts tearing it violently to pieces. He rips off the banners, the pennants, the signs, the flags, flinging them onto the blacktop, stomping on t grinding them under his heels, flailing the wooden poles held them against the side of the car until they splinter Then he reaches through the window into the glove compart snatches up something, and comes running back,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben and the others have stepped into the open doorway watch him. Hysterical, the man charges up at him, scrabbl through a box of cartridges, grabs a bullet and rams it i Reuben's belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben looks down at the gleaming copper cartridge, then up at Wayne's face, trembling with the ague of uncontroll Lage.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Man, you can't do it that way. What you've got to do is get a gun, put that thing in a chamber, point it at a guy, and pull the trigger. That's how you do it. ) Wayne's head is shaking from side to side; otherwise, he paralyzed. Reuben takes the bullet from his hand, lifts t hand, opens the palm, holds the bullet suspended above it then drops it in.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBIN ROOM 153
dialogues.text: Vernon works at an accelerated clip, the bobbins reeling yarn. He is like a man at stoop labor, bending, rising, bending, rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly sits down on the floor, his eyes closed. The bobbins keep jerking up and down before him, . Jimmy Jerome Davis comes over, puts his face down close s he can hear,

dialogues.speaker: VERNON
dialogues.text: I don't feel too good. Like to go lie down.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY JEROME
dialogues.text: You got a break coming up in fifteen minutes, Vernon.
I need to go now,

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY JEROME
dialogues.text: You hold on, Vernon. Your preak's coming up. He pats Vernon on the back and walks on,

dialogues.speaker: VERNON 155
dialogues.text: He tries to resume work and then falls into the bobbins. They continue to pump up and down around his inert body.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVEYARD 156
dialogues.text: Like everything else in Millageville, the graveyard is ha harsh, graves wrested out of rocky soil. People who have spent their lives in unremitting work come to a stony res place here, Norma, Leona, the children, Sonny, uncomfortable in a dar suit, stand by the open grave as the pine box is lowered. Reuben and a group of mill hands, friends of Vernon's, st at a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck lumbers past the mourners, backs up to the open g The grave diggers step out of the way. The tailgate drops down; white sand sifts down onto the pine box in a steady stream, slowly covering it. Norma turns to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: . NORMA
dialogues.text: I just couldn't stand the thought of dirt going over him like that. The white sand now completely covers the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sudden movement among the factory workers. As the grave is closed, a few of them move toward Norma. They pay their last respects to Vernon Witchard by placin in Norma's hand a signed blue union card.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 159
dialogues.text: She holds three or four cards in her hand and turns to lo at Reuben,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (harshly) - Somebody's gotta die to get ‘em, .

dialogues.speaker: INT, MOTEL 160
dialogues.text: Two men enter the tiny lobby. AL LONDON and SAM DAKIN are both middle-aged, matter-of-fact, tough, seasoned. They g past the desk clerk without a word, turn down the hall,

dialogues.speaker: INT, HALL 161
dialogues.text: They stride through the dark corridor, looking at room numbers, They find the number they want, knock. There is no answer. They throw the door open and move in,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO 558

dialogues.speaker: INT, REUBEN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: 82 162 It is late and Norma, exhausted, has thrown clutter off t bed, curled up on it and fallen into a deep sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163 She awakens with a start to find two strangers standing i the doorway and looking down at her. Norma stands.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Who are you looking for? The two men are present on business and have no time for amenities.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Warshovsky around?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: He's at the printer's,

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Pretty late for the printer's...

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Reuben keeps him working late.

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: We'll talk to you 'til he gets back. You're Norma Rae, aren't you? :

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (sensing hostility) I'm Missus Webster.

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: We're from the union. National headquarters, (points to the other man) Al London, And I'm Sam Dakin.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: As long as you're here, I'll give you my shopping list. We need envelopes, we need typing paper, we need stamps, we. need a loudspeaker, we could use a couple more typewriters that don't stick. cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 163 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Yo We're not in office supplies, Cy Missus Webster. Sat

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're not around much, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Reuben walks in. If he is surprised to see the men, he doesn't show it. They shake hands all around.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: How are you, Sam? You've gotten fat.

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I put on a couple of pounds.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: How are you, Al?

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Lousy, I got a cold, There is an awkward pause,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: What brings you?

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: You're not getting up much of @ head of steam, Reuben.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You've had my reports, You know what I'm up against.

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: We're worried,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: That makes three of us.

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: This is a small Baptist Southern town. We have to keep our noses very clean. 2 Cont. 558  558 84 164 cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (reacting to the pressure ) You see any snot on mine?

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: Maybe Missus Webster would like to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Norma turns to go, Reuben raises a hand. She stops in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Why should she leave?

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: This concerns her, I'm trying to make it easy for her.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (irritably) Come on, come on, it's late. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: The company wants us to look bad. They're going to use everything they can to make us look bad. You know, these mill hands go to church every Sunday, and she's talking union to 'em, (pauses slightly) They say she was in a porno movie, with a member of the local police department, Very explicit.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Show it to me. Run it for me,

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: There doesn't have to be a movie if there's talk that there is one. This lady has had an illegitimate child. She's slept around. She takes naps on your bed late at night. Cont.  558 85 165 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this? Are we in the character assassination business or are we in the union business? All of a sudden, after I've put in an eighteen hour day, I got the legion of decency on my hands! She's been breaking her ass for this organization. She doesn't see her kids, she doesn't have time to take a bath! What the fuck - do I care if she's got round heels? Is this the Catholic Church?...Are we going to canonize her? What the shit is this!

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: This is your show, Reuben...but maybe she ought to go.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Make it stick. If you can't, get out of here. (throws open the door) Get out of here anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DAKIN
dialogues.text: (to Norma) I'm sorry about this, Mrs. Webster, It's part of my job -- but I could do without it. He motions to London. The two men leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma and Reuben are alone in the room. She is grateful f his defense but aware of the gravity of the situation. Neither speaks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't hurt the union, If you want me to quit, I will.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (irritably) How come you were sleeping? I asked you to type those letters, She goes to the typewriter, rubbing a sore spot in her ba He jams a cigar in his mouth and goes back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma gets out of her car, hauling a bag of groceries wit her. Her mother is in a chair on the front porch, solitar motionless, the evening paper unread across her lap. A garden hose drips water on her plants in coffee cans li the porch. Norma hails her as she crosses the lawn,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I brought you laundry soap, I brought you bread, I brought you some ground chuck -- it was on sale,

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: Sit down, you look perspired. With a groan, Norma puts the bag down, sits on the top st at her mother's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why those housewives have to shop just when we get off our shift.

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: I've told you, you don't have to market for me. I can go over to the store after supper, when it's cool, and get my few little things.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: If I didn't market, you wouldn't eat anything. You'd eat crackers and drink coffee. Anyway -- it gives me a chance to come and sit down and talk to you. (looks up at her) Momma, you been crying?

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: I was thinking of your daddy. (pauses ) I was thinking how short a person's life is. You gotta hurry to catch your goals, Don't let the days pass...your daddy was a young man, then he was an old one. I wonder -- did he leave things undone? Did he leave things unsaid? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 167 Cont. LEONA (Cont.) (looks at her daughter) Child, if there's something you want, don't wait all the way down the line to get it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Was there something you wanted you didn't get?

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: If there was, I've forgotten it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Momma, wouldn't you like to come and stay with me? The kids are around, they make a lot of noise, it's cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: I'm used to this house,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (worried) What if you fall down the steps? What if you fall in the bathtub? What if something happens to you?

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: Then it will. Norma suddenly reaches for her mother's hand and kisses i

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: Now what was that for?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: For you -- and for me, (rises) I'm going in and boil you an ‘egg.

dialogues.speaker: LEONA
dialogues.text: No, let's just sit out here and rest a while, Norma sits again, leaning back against her mother's knee, Leona strokes her hair. 558  ry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every inch of space is now in full use; even the bathtub crammed with cartons and papers. PULL BACK. Somehow a card table has been wedged into the bathroom and two girl sit facing each other at typewriters, hard at it.

dialogues.speaker: INT, MOTEL ROOM 169
dialogues.text: A dozen people fill the single motel room, stuffing envelopes, addressing them, checking off lists, on the telephones. PETER GALLAT comes through the door and Norma, looking up from her work table, attacks him immediately.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You get off your shift. at three, you're supposed to be here at three-fifteen, and it's four-fifteen! Where the hell you been? You working for this union or aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was getting my tooth filled.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You were getting your beer gut filled!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Chew your old man out at home and get off me, Norma.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm just starting on you. I'm giving, nine, ten, eleven, twelve hours. And that's every day! There's a pile of work around here. We're doing our piece of it, you do your piece of it -- or don't call yourself a union member!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben unwinds himself from his crowded desk, rises slowl and walks over, Norma finds herself face to face with him

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (coldly) Shut your cake-hole, Norma. Her face mirrors her astonishment at his sudden, brusque attack. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 EE eee ae 89 170 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: In fact, get the hell out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do? I just said what was SO. From its cacophony of SOUND, the room has suddenly BECOME VERY STILL. Reuben shows her his thumb, jabbing it toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Out. For a moment, she does nothing. Then, quite simply, she turns to look for her purse, picks it up and walks out. The silence in. thé room persists.

dialogues.speaker: INT, COFFEE SHOP 171
dialogues.text: In the shop attached to the motel, looking out on the scummy pool, Norma sits alone over a cup of coffee and a wedge of pie. But the food remains untouched before her. She is thinking. The door swings open and Reuben. enters, looking around. sees her and ambles over, slides into the booth across fr her. He looks at her for a long, level moment.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Mouth. She says nothing. He takes her fork, samples her pie, lik it, pulls it toward him and begins to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You're too muscular. You can't come down that hard on a man and leave him his balls. Easy, Norma. Easy does it. Jesus. If you were in the State Department, we'd be at war.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're right. I got a big mouth. (pauses) You know, cotton mill workers are known as trash by some, and I know this union is the only way we can have our own voice and make ourselves better. I guess that's why I push. Cont.  a a a a IEEE SES 558 90 171 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Our own Mother Jones,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: She was a considerable lady. She made it happen for coal miners in West Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Then you're not sore at me?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: If the situation called for a smart, loud, profane, sloppy, hard-working woman, I'd pick you every time out.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (after a moment ) How come sloppy? Nobody wears a girdle anymore. But she is pleased. and placated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress is at their table, holding a check.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (rising) Give it to her. I didn't order anything.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well, hell, you ate it. But he is already striding out the door, going back to wo Norma rummages in her purse for some change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Davis is tacking up a notice on the bulletin board the weaving room. Very large black letters command the reader: ALL EMPLOYEES ATTENTION

dialogues.speaker: PHONE BOOTH 174
dialogues.text: An agitated Norma is on the phone, impatiently listening to the RINGS. At last the other end is picked up. Cont.
91 174 cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's me, Norma. All right, it is I, Norma. Forget the grammar -- T gotta see you right away. Meet me on my break. She hangs up, steps out, comes face to face with Tommy Gardner. She speaks to him airily.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Calling my kids to see if they got home from school.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (nailing the lie) Your kids are in the grocery store with my kids, buying candy. They do it every day.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Maybe that's why my dentist's bills are busting me. And she walks back to work.

dialogues.speaker: A YARD 175
dialogues.text: A fight breaks out, one of the white workers rounding on black, sending him dazed to his knees with a violent blow The black is up instantly and at the white: a close-in, savage fight. In the next moment, the confrontation expan four whites join in, half a dozen blacks meet them, more whites advance. There is now a general melee in the yard. There is an uproar as each side champions its own. Company men come on the run to quell it.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FENCE
dialogues.text: Norma and Reuben meet. They prowl the fence between them.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: What started it?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: They put up a letter. They're telling the whites that the blacks _ @re gonna run the union, take it -over and push 'em around. You tell a white man that a black man is gonna sit on his head -- (gestures ) -- and this is what you get. Cont.  g2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 176 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I like it when those pricks get | mean. We can take legal action. Get me the letter.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I can't just waltz in and take it off the board. They're watching.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: How good's your memory? t

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well -- I still don't know the whole salute to the flag. i

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Get somebody to help you. Learn , a line at a time. Write it down.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (hesitates a moment) It reminds me of the time I pinched a lipstick out of the five and dime.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Did you get caught?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No. I went back the next week for curlers.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Then you ought to know how. They separate, each going quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipping from a paper cup on her coffee break, Norma saunt toward the bulletin board and past it. She turns with elaborate nonchalance, comes back and stops in front of i She reads quickly, then shuts her eyes tight, her mouth moving. She hits her head with the palm of her hand, as i to drive the information home. Then she hurries to the ladies room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bonnie ambles by the bulletin board, pauses, looks at intently for a long moment, then hurries after Norma,

dialogues.speaker: INT, LADIES' ROOM 179
dialogues.text: as Bonnie enters. Norma is busy leaning on the sink, writ on a piece of toilet paper with an eyebrow pencil. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: i | I79 Cont. | iy NORMA i (muttering O ',..you black employees are being told that by going into the union in mass you can dominate it and control it in this plant as you may : see fit. If now...! : (hesitates ) : oe 'If now...! (lost it) Damn! What's next? I can't ; ‘ remember. : ! t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonnie has in the meantime gotten pencil and paper ready, licked the point of the pencil, but has drawn a total bla

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: (wailing) Norma, I can't remember the first word. My God, I forgot it. from out there to in here.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Think of it like a song. If it ( was a Dolly Parton song, you'd CB remember it. Sing it if you gotta.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Did you get some?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I got a piece of it. She folds the toilet paper and puts it down her bra. Bonnie now views it as a conspiratorial romp.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Norma. Do you suppose they got x a@ microphone in here. Norma is overcome with the same giddy mood.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't put it past ‘em. x She tiptoes to the towel dispenser and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: ( Am I talking loud enough? Are xX . you listening, 0.P.? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: 558 94 180 cont. Bonnie goes to the mirror and waggles her hand at it, as _ it concealed a viewer on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Yoo-hoo, Yoo-hoo. Norma goes to the trash can and bends over to it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hey! This is me. Correction. It is I. Both women break up in gales of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long strip of toilet paper with a black scrawl from one end to the other. PULL BACK. It is night. Reuben is holding Norma's transcription at arm's length, reading it. He puts it dow and turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Where's the rest?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's the most I could get.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Mata Hari.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: They were watching us every minute. He sees the futility of it and his voice hardens.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It's the best chance we've got to nail these bastards, to get 'em with their pants down. They got their butts in an icy wind this time. Don't tell me you can't remember it, you can't get it. Walk up to it, stand there, copy it down, word for word, line for line. Get the date, get the signature, get it all -- and get it back to me!

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'll get fired. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 181 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: 0 I'll run you a benefit. She gives him an odd look. She has had a hard line from men before. :

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. ‘ He is excited, goaded, tired, tense. Things are coming to a head.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: If you want to get massaged, go to @ massage parlor. You either get licked or you don't get licked.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Listen. I got three kids. I got a drawer full of bills. I got a husband doesn't like what I'm doing. I'll do it. But I don't need your boot on my backside, Mister Warshovsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CS He pours himself a cup of coffee from the plug-in coff a maker, stands looking down into it.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Goddamn sludge has been standing here for three days... There is a silence. She looks at him calmly, cooliy.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm going to tell you something, Reuben,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: What are you going to tell me, Norma?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You been away from home a long time. You been all business. You're getting crabby. You need @ woman.

dialogues.text: Funny you should mention it. Tonight's the night. “558 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVISED - “NORMA RAE" - 3/27/78 96 182 Cont. He puts down the cup, yanks his jacket off the back of a chair, struggles into it. He starts for the door. She can't resist a parting shot.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I wonder what Dorothy'd say.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Wear a rubber. He slams out.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 183
dialogues.text: Clipboard in hand, she goes straight to the bulletin boar She writes briskly, snatching a phrase off the letter wit a glance, then looking down as her hand scrawls quickly. In order to transcribe accurately, she prounounces each phrase aloud.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (quoting) ',..that where unions are strikes occur, Strikes: mean loss of work, loss of pay, and often loss of jobs...Strike and trouble, which often end up in serious violence...'
