dialogues.text: Rick Iujan is beside her. He means business.

dialogues.speaker: LUJAN
dialogues.text: You can't take down that letter. x

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's up here on the bulletin x° board -- and I'm gonna copy it. Dan Peters joins them.

dialogues.speaker: PETERS
dialogues.text: Norma, you better not. x

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (dogged) Dan, I'm gonna take down every x word of this letter. It's my break time, and I'm gonna take down every word of this letter. He reaches out as if to take her arm and stop her, but sh pulls away fiercely. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ! REVISED - "NORMA RAE" - 3/27/78 of | 184 Cont. | ‘ | i, NORMA | ON Just keep out of my way! I'm | CU gonna take down this letter! | Now Leroy Mason approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ) Hello, Norma. |

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Mr. Mason, you know who ' I am. )

dialogues.speaker: , MASON '
dialogues.text: , Norma, you just put your pencil , and paper away.
' She ignores him and continues to write as rapidly as sh I i

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: You just stop what you're doing \ -- right now -- ‘cause you're | . about to leave. ' She whirls around. '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: aan You better not put a hand on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the three men take a step back, two of them looking at Mason to see what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: The law's coming and it's gonna take you right out of this plant.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Mr. Mason, I started this and -- I'm gonna finish this -- The three men are stunned into silence and inactivity. Sh turns back to the board and calmly finishes her task. The she folds her notes, shoves them in her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PETERS
dialogues.text: Let's go to the office, Norma. She goes with the two men, back across the long hall, peo ( turning to watch. 558

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: x

dialogues.speaker: INT, MASON'S OFFICE 187
dialogues.text: A number of men are arrayed in force against her: Lujan, Peters, Moody, Alston, Mason. Mason descends on her stern

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Why did you make personal phone calls on company time? By way of reply she suddenly whips out pencil and paper.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'd like you to spell out your name for me.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Now you're being foolish, Norma Rae. She drops the pencil and paper in her lap, puts her hands over her ears and closes her eyes, embattled.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Mason, nobody's on my side around here, and I'm not gonna leave until I set down all your names on this piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: (exploding ) I don't want you on the premises. You make a phone call to your husband and tell him to come fetch you. I want you out of here right quick. She stays planted in her chair, eyes closed, hands over h ears. She is beginning to show the strain.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to call the law to get rid of me. And you better make it the Sheriff, too. It better be Sheriff Lamar Miller to come get me, it better be him, it better not be any policeman, 'cause he was a friend of my daddy's. I got a jealous husband and he knows Lamar and I won't just go with anybody. Lamar Miller's the Sheriff.of Millageville so he better be the one. She gets up without another word and walks out of the off  558 ce ENE SEE A SE

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FLOOR 188
dialogues.text: She goes back to the looms but she does no work! She mere stands there. Everyone on the floor stands in silence, attentive. The room is charged with tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PINKERTON MAN in uniform comes toward her. When he is about ten feet away, she raises her hand. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (singing it out) Forget it. I'm staying put -- x right where I am. The man shrugs, turns and leaves. She looks around the fl All eyes are on her. She stands rigid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a SOUND of a DOOR SLAMMING, a GREAT METALLIC CLA Now a CITY POLICEMAN is warily approaching her. She waits until he is close and then she shouts, so that the man is halted in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's gonna take you and the x police department and the fire department and the National Guard to get me out of here. The Policeman hesitates, vacillates, then takes another rather uncertain step or two forward. Norma, concerned, backs away.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm waiting on the Sheriff to x come drive me home and I'm not budging until he arrives. But the Policeman continues to shuffle toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At bay, surrounded, alone, the pressure intense, she suddenly reaches around behind her and fumbles for a shee of stiff cardboard. She grabs lipstick, and with one eye on the Policeman, she strikes off some heavy block letter on the cardboard. Then with one thrust, she hoists hersel up on top of a radiator and stands on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone on the floor is watching her, Bonnie close to te Leona shaken and tense, James Brown, George Hubbard, Ray Buck, frustrated, immobilized, awaiting the outcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pee ss ee . wo ee ee a

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 193
dialogues.text: ! She holds her sign high over her head with both hands a | rN slowly turns in a circle so that everyone on the ope | Lo all focused entirely on her, can read what she has w i "UNION"

dialogues.speaker: THE MILL HANDS
dialogues.text: It is as if her upraised sign is an igniting torch to the blaze that follows. The first hand to rise, signalling response, is her mother's. Slowly, the old woman's arm : rises above her head and stays there. The man next to i her follows suit. James Brown raises his. Lucius White ! is next. George Hubbard follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mill hands follow suit; one by one they join. Norma looks down to see the Pinkerton, the Policeman, and a forelady, AGNES ROY. The woman calls up to her:

dialogues.speaker: AGNES ROY
dialogues.text: Norma, just climb on down. It's xX i no good your standing there. a ANOTHER ANGLE 196 Ss SS Norma doesn't answer. She continues to turn slowly, showing the word. Each time she turns, another batch of hands shoot up, holding their arms in the air, black and white, responding to her exhortation. Finally, the entire floor is a forest of upraised hands, which seem to be puoying her up and carrying her with their silent support

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 197
dialogues.text: Finished, she climbs down. Walking toward her is LAMAR MILLER, Chief of Police, unbuttoned coat showing hi pistol.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Come on, now, Norma, Come on.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (fixing him) Lamar, before I budge from here, x you're gonna put into writing that Sheriff Lamar Miller, will take Norma Rae Webster straight home, You sign it and give me that piece of paper. Se Cont. 558

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 197 Cont. The bossmen look on in amazement as Lamar begins to compl Then he suddenly balis up the paper and flings it on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Don't tell me what to do, young x lady. You're not gonna get anything in writing off of me. turns to Mason) You want her removed from the premises?

dialogues.speaker: MASON
dialogues.text: Get her out of here. x Miller turns back to Norma.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: I don't know that I want to get x into that automobile with you and nobody else.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Lamar, I'm not gonna bite you. xX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to take her purse, puts it under her arm, and leads the way, Miller, the Policeman, and the Pinkerton in a line behind her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MILL 199
dialogues.text: as they emerge, Norma sees two cars in front of her, an unmarked car and a police car. She stops short.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's a police car! You're taking me to jail! Behind her she hears the chain link fence beginning to cl She spins around, dropping the rug and the purse, and rec for the fence, gripping the gate, hooking her fingers through the links, hanging on fiercely, swinging with it it is banged shut and locked. The Policeman and the Pinkerton are after her.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Now quit that scrapping. You're xX going where I take you -- and that's to jail. Cont. _ ey  103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she is led past the drunk tank, past a row of empty cells to her own. It is ten feet long, five feet wide, a dim light burning in it, bunk beds, a toilet, a wash basin.

dialogues.speaker: THE CELL 205
dialogues.text: She steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: You might as well sit down. But she remains standing. Miller appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: You got one phone call, Norma. You better call Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm calling my union organizer.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Here's your dime. He hands her a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reuben is driving. No emotion is visible on Norma's face. She stares directly ahead of her. Reuben looks at her once or twice. They are silent. He speaks at last, gently

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: The first time you're in is bad. The planes of her face begin to break up. She fights against it, succeeds for a moment, then gives way. She begins to weep, bitter tears -- she has been outraged and demeaned. Tears come hard to her and only an experience like this could bring them. Reuben gives her time to release it all before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It comes with the job. I've seen a pregnant woman on a picket line hit in the stomach with a elub. I've seen a boy of sixteen shot in the back. I've seen a man blown to hell and gone when he started his car one morning. (quietly) You just got your feet wet on this one. She stops crying instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 ee REVISED - “NORMA RAE" - 3/27/78 102 199 Cont. They grab her arms, pry her fingers loose, wrench her awa Holding her by the arms they rush her to the police cruis shoving her head down, stuffing her into the backseat, Slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around, feeling trapped. There are no door handles, no window cranks. A thick wire mesh separates her from the front seat. Miller and the Policeman get in the front, the latter breathing heavily from his exertion. The car pulls away, the dark bulk of the mill looming behind them.

dialogues.speaker: INT, JAIL 201
dialogues.text: Norma goes straight to the magistrate's couch and lies do flat on it, disdainful and removing herself from the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 202
dialogues.text: Her face is impassive as she listens to Miller dictating the warrant for her arrest.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Webster, Norma Rae, 305 Jackson x Street, Millageville. Female. White. Thirty-two. Occupation -- textile, Light complexion. Brown hair. Brown eyes. Arrest Number: 2416-3. Charge -- Disorderly Conduct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavyset MATRON appears. Miller turns away from the des SERGEANT to Norma.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: You go with her, Norma. Wordlessly, she rises from .the couch,  a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny gets up hurriedly as he hears them coming, concern on his face. Norma enters with Reuben behind her. Husband and wife are face to face.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You all right, Norma? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I put the kids to bed. She nods again, then goes past him into the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkened room, Norma goes to a shelf in the closet and hauls down a metal box. Then she goes from cot to cot and gently wakes the three children, all asleep in the same room.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Craig, honey, wake up...Millie, honey, it's Momma, get up... Alice, sweetheart, come in the other room. The children get up slowly, rubbing their eyes. She helps them out of bed, shepherds them with her back into the other room.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LIVING ROOM 209
dialogues.text: Norma sits with her children on either side of her, leani against her, still half-asleep, Alice sprawled in her lap The two men sit across the room and watch, not intruding.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I love you children, that's first. And Sonny loves you. You got both of us. The second thing is, I'm a jJailbird. You're gonna hear that and a lot of other things, but you're gonna hear ‘em from me first. The children look up at her, awake now, alert. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 558 She hugs 105 209 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Millie, your real daddy was named Buddy Wilson and he died four months after you were born. Craig, I never was married to your daddy, and your daddy was not Sonny and not Buddy, but another man. And there were some others in my life and they'll be telling you about them, too. (reaches into the box, takes out papers and photographs) I got pictures of Craig's father in here. for him, and pictures of Millie's father for her. Craig, I got settlement papers in here made between me and your daddy; this is your stuff. It's not mine, it's yours. It's your life. (puts the papers in his lap) I want you to feel there's nothing you can't come to me and talk to me about. If you go into the mill, I want life to be better for you than it is for me; that's why I joined up with the union and got “fired for it. I'm not making excuses for myself -- like everybody else, I'm not perfect and I made these mistakes. But I hope you'll learn from my experiences that life has a meaning; there is a moral reason for why you should do this and why you shouldn't do this. (pauses ) Now you kids know that I've cleaned out my closet. You know what I am and you know that I believe in standing up for my rights. them, each in turn, and they hug her back. ‘NORMA ‘Go to the bathroom before you go back to bed. Cont.  558

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 209 Cont.1 The children turn and go out of the room, holding their pictures and their papers carefully, as if they were thin of value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma rises.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go take a bath now. They had lice in that jail. She walks out of the room, leaving the two men alone. Son looks across the room at Reuben trying to assay what position he has in Norma's life.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: She had one call and she called you.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) She knew I could make bail.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You come in here, you mix her up, you turn her head all around. She's all changed. I didn't want her to be a front-runner -- I didn't want that. What's gonna happen to us now?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: She stood up on a table. She's a free woman. Maybe you can live with it -- maybe you can't. He turns and walks out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma is in bed, her hands behind her head, awake, silent turned inward. Sonny enters from the bathroom, ready for bed. His shoes are in his way; he bends to pick them up and move them.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Got a broken shoelace...

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: There's another pair in the drawer. Cont.  a REESE S SESSA SS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 211 cont. |

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Busted those last week. al He gets into bed with her. They lie side by side. Ther i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: j is something on his mind, hard to bring forth, hard to | articulate, He finally does so, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: . SONNY
dialogues.text: Did you ever sleep with him? No. (pauses) But he's’ in my ‘head.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Sonny is silent for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I'll see you through getting tired, getting sick, getting old. I'11 see you through anything that comes up. 'Cause there's nobody else in my head. Just you. He turns out the light, turns his back to her. ‘She lies ( in the darkened room a moment, then places her hand on Oo back in a gesture of response.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STREET 212
dialogues.text: Dense with a crowd of mill hands, a pervasive silence hanging over them as they throng the street from curb to curb, restless, charged, waiting, simmering in the heat of the late afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA 213
dialogues.text: She paces outside the gate, alone in the crowd, her hands thrust in her pockets, intent on the iron balcony high in the side of the plant, waiting to see a figure, to hear a sound, to receive word. This is the moment of promise, the moment of fulfillment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is jammed, men sweating in the close confines o the room. There are a dozen men with tags across their shirt fronts. A dozen newspaper and television reporters observe and record, flashbulbs going off now and then. 558  108 ‘AT THE LONG TABLE 215 The men here are divided into two groups, half of them BOSSMEN from the company, the other half UNION MEN. Huge stacks of paper ballots are being tabulated from the "NO" and "YES" piles. The tension is palpable, each piece of paper a victory or a@loss. Management is frozen-faced and silent. There are no smiles, no talk. Men-stand up on chairs to crane and watch the.count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Brown hoists Bonnie up on his chair, shares it with her so that she too can see. They share hope as the ballots are shuffled, as the two piles diminish, as the silent marks are made, for and against.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE REAR 217
dialogues.text: an OLD MAN, pressed against the wall by the crowd, begins to weep, unable any longer to withstand the suspense, is ashamed, reaches for a soiled handkerchief, surreptitious wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LINETTE ODUM 218
dialogues.text: mashed among the people, she holds a snapshot against her chest, turns it to look down at it -- it is the visag of a middle-aged man, gaunt, wasted. She looks from the snapshot to the tabulators, back and forth, back and forth, waiting to be avenged.

dialogues.speaker: A YOUNG WOMAN 219
dialogues.text: blonde, frail, in the stifling heat and the crush, she suddenly faints. The pack is so great that she does not fall, is held up by the bodies around her, merely sags against a MAN besid her. He holds her, “takés a knotted kerchief from his nec and mops her brow, looks around.for a way to get her out. But there is no way, so he supports her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a stir, a final shuffling of feet, then absolute silence as a labor board AGENT raises his hand at the tab Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pe ee a A ene 109 220 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Ballots tabulated for the C) O.P. Henley Company against the Union -- one thousand four hundred and forty-eight votes. (pauses, looks at another slip in kis hand) Ballots tabulated for the Union -- one thousand six hundred and eighty-five.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL 221
dialogues.text: There is a tumultuous, roaring shout from the assembled mill hands, a hosanna of triumph. The open-throated outery goes on and on and on.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN 222
dialogues.text: at the back of the room, near the door, he spins on his heel and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, GATE
dialogues.text: Norma, outside the gate, stops her pacing as Reuben emerg and stands’ a moment on the balcony. They stand motionles So looking at each other, across the distance that separa them. Then he starts down toward her, NORMA AND REUBEN 22h as he comes up to her. He says only one word.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Did we trounce 'em?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: We did good enough. They walk along together, pushing through the crowd. Behind them, up on the balcony, a MAN comes out and shout to the crowd below: Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 224 cont. | i Oo We beat ‘em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roar goes up in the street, men and women clapping i one another on the back, hugging one another, men hugging , men, women, women.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA AND REUBEN 225
dialogues.text: They turn a corner and are alone. They walk toward his car parked at the curb, front seat sagging under books, suitcases and cartons jammed in the back, obscuring the rear window.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You gonna drive straight through?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Better stop for coffee. Stay awake.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN ,
dialogues.text: I got a thermos in the car. 1 Cy NORMA Well.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Well. They have reached the car. NORMA AND REUBEN 226 ;

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Live. What else?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: This town going to be big enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: If it isn't, I'll spread out.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Drop me a line once in awhile. ~ Cont.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: rm Le 558 There is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 226 Cont. NORMA © Does anybody read your mail?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Just my mother. a pause.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I'll send you a copy of Dylan Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I already bought one for myself.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Nobody can do anything for you, huh?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You've done something for me. Lots.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: You did something for us. A mitzvah.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: A good work. (pauses) : I never say good-bye. I've been known to cry.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What do you say,. then?

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Be well. Be happy.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You, too,

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances, best wishes hardly seem enough. Thanks are in order. Thank you for your companionship, for your stamina, your horse sense, and a hundred and one laughs. I also enjoyed looking at your shining hair and your shining face. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Reuben, I think you like me.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I do. :

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I was gonna get you a tie clip or some shaving lotion, but 1 didn't know what you'd like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma, what I've had from you has been sumptuous. 112 226 Cont.1 He holds out his hand, she holds out hers, they shake. It is ho mere ritual of farewell; the touch held and held and held. But it must end. They are comrades-in-arms, is held and they are battle-weary, they are triumphant. Whatever else they might be remains unspoken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @s Reuben gets into his car and drives away. there. She is all there.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: 227 Norma stands
